an5:1.2.3_0: Faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an5:1.3.2_0: ‘We will have the trainee’s powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.’

an5:101.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five qualities make a trainee assured.
an5:101.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:101.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, ethical, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.
an5:101.2.1_0: A person of faith doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who lacks faith.
an5:101.2.2_0: That’s why the teaching of a trainee assured.
an5:101.3.1_0: An ethical person doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who is unethical.
an5:101.3.2_0: That’s why the teaching of a trainee assured.
an5:101.4.1_0: A learned person doesn’t have the insecurities of a person of little learning.
an5:101.4.2_0: That’s why the teaching of a trainee assured.
an5:101.5.1_0: An energetic person doesn’t have the insecurities of a lazy person.
an5:101.5.2_0: That’s why the teaching of a trainee assured.
an5:101.6.1_0: A wise person doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who is witless.
an5:101.6.2_0: That’s why the teaching of a trainee assured.
an5:101.6.3_0: These are the five qualities that make a trainee assured.”
an5:101.6.4_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:102.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a monk should be suspected and distrusted from five bad qualities.
an5:102.2.2_0: It’s when a monk frequently collects alms from prostitutes, widows, voluptuous girls, eunuchs, or nuns.
an5:102.3.1_0: Even if a monk is of impeccable character, he might be suspected and distrusted as a ‘bad monk’ for these five reasons.”
an5:103.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a master thief with five factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.
an5:103.1.3_0: A master thief relies on rough ground, on thick cover, and on powerful individuals; they pay bribes, and they act alone.
an5:103.10.1_0: And how does a bad mendicant rely on rough ground?
an5:103.10.2_0: It’s when a bad mendicant has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.
an5:103.10.3_0: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on uneven ground.
an5:103.11.1_0: And how does a bad mendicant rely on uneven ground?
an5:103.11.2_0: It’s when a bad mendicant minists their minister or their minister.
an5:103.11.4_0: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, or rulers will ministers!’
an5:103.11.5_0: If anyone says such a thing, it is considering for them.
an5:103.11.6_0: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on thick cover.
an5:103.12.1_0: And how does a bad mendicant pay bribes?
an5:103.12.2_0: It’s when a bad mendicant receives robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an5:103.12.4_0: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, I’ll settle it with a bribe.’
an5:103.12.6_0: That’s how a bad mendicant pays bribes.
an5:103.13.1_0: And how does a bad mendicant act alone?
an5:103.13.2_0: It’s when a bad mendicant dwells alone in the borderlands.
an5:103.13.3_0: They visit families there to get material possessions.
an5:103.13.4_0: That’s how a bad mendicant acts alone.
an5:103.14.1_0: When a bad mendicant has these five factors, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they make much bad karma.”
an5:103.2.1_0: And how does a master thief rely on uneven ground?
an5:103.2.2_0: It’s when a master thief carries out to the mountain, Vedas,
an5:103.2.3_0: That’s how a master thief relies on uneven ground.
an5:103.3.1_0: And how does a master thief rely on rough ground?
an5:103.3.2_0: It’s when a master thief relies on thick grass, thick trees, a ridge, or a large dense wood.
an5:103.3.3_0: That’s how a master thief relies on uneven ground.
an5:103.4.1_0: And how does a master thief rely on uneven ground?
an5:103.4.2_0: It’s when a master thief relies on their minister or their minister.
an5:103.4.4_0: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, or rulers will ministers!’
an5:103.4.5_0: If anyone says such a thing, it is considering for them.
an5:103.4.6_0: That’s how a master thief relies on uneven ground.
an5:103.5.1_0: And how does a master thief pay bribes?
an5:103.5.2_0: It’s when a master thief is rich, affluent, and wealthy.
an5:103.5.4_0: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, I’ll settle it with a bribe.’
an5:103.5.6_0: That’s how a master thief pays bribes.
an5:103.6.1_0: And how does a master thief act alone?
an5:103.6.2_0: It’s when a master thief carries out robbery all alone.
an5:103.6.4_0: So that their secret plans are not leaked to others.
an5:103.6.5_0: That’s how a master thief acts alone.
an5:103.7.1_0: A master thief with these five factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.
an5:103.8.1_0: In the same way, when a bad mendicant has five factors, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they make much bad karma.
an5:103.8.3_0: A bad mendicant relies on rough ground, on thick cover, and on powerful individuals; they pay bribes, and they act alone.
an5:103.9.1_0: And how does a bad mendicant rely on uneven ground?
an5:103.9.2_0: It’s when a bad mendicant has uncondered by deeds by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:103.9.3_0: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on uneven ground.

an5:104.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is an exquisite ascetic of ascetics.
an5:104.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant usually uses only what they’ve been invited to accept.
an5:104.2.2_1: if she usually uses almsfood, and is invited to accept alms-food;
an5:104.2.2_3: usually use only what they’ve been invited to accept ...
an5:104.2.3_0: When living with other spiritual practitioners, they usually treat them agreeably by way of body, speech, and mind, rarely disagreeably.
an5:104.2.3_1: usually by kindness by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:104.2.3_2: Patience, they usually treat them agreeably by disagreeable,
an5:104.2.4_0: And I usually present them with agreeable things.
an5:104.2.5_0: They’re healthy, so the various unpleasant feelings—stemming from disorders of bile, phlegm, wind, or their conjunction; or caused by change in weather, by not taking care of themselves, by overexertion, or as the result of past deeds—usually don’t come up.
an5:104.2.6_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:104.2.7_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:104.2.8_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is an exquisite ascetic of ascetics.
an5:104.3.1_0: For if anyone should be rightly called ‘an all-round snare of Māra’, it’s females.

an5:105.1.1_0: “There are these five kinds of comfort.
an5:105.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:105.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
an5:105.1.3_1: and mind, both in public and in private.
an5:105.1.4_0: They live according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
an5:105.1.5_0: They live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
an5:106.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
an5:106.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an5:106.2.1_0: “Sir, how could a mendicant live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”
an5:106.2.2_0: “It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.
an5:106.2.3_0: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”
an5:106.3.1_0: “But sir, might there be another way for a mendicant to live comfortably while staying in a monastic community?”
an5:106.3.2_0: “Ānanda, there are five kinds of people.
an5:106.3.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in their own ethical conduct, but they don’t urge others to be ethical.
an5:106.3.4_0: But they don’t send themselves away like this,
an5:106.3.5_0: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5:106.4.5_0: They’re not anxious and they don’t become anxious because of wisdom.
an5:106.4.6_0: That’s how a mendicant could live comfortably while staying in a monastic community.”

an5:107.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an5:107.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant is accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:107.3.1_0: A mendicant with these five factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
an5:108.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an5:108.2.2_0: It’s when they have the entire spectrum of the master’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:108.2.3_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods ...
an5:108.2.3_1: the supreme field of merit for the world.”
an5:109.0.3_0: Under the Lord of the Deathless
an5:109.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is at ease in any quarter.
an5:109.1.3_0: It’s when mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5:109.1.4_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:109.1.5_0: They’re content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an5:109.1.6_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:109.1.7_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:109.1.8_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is at ease in any quarter.”
an5:11.0.3_0: Under the sway of the body.
an5:11.1.1_0: “I claim to have attained perfection and consummation of insight regarding principles not learned before from another.
an5:11.1.2_0: The Realized One has five powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
an5:11.1.4_0: Faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.
an5:11.1.5_0: These are the five powers of a Realized One. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.”
an5:11.1.6_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:110.1.10_0: The first sub-chapter on living at ease is finished.
an5:110.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has five qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an5:110.1.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5:110.1.4_0: He has learned much, and he retained them in good qualities.
an5:110.1.5_0: They live with energy roused up, strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5:110.1.6_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:110.1.7_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:110.1.8_0: When a mendicant has these five qualities they’re ready to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.”
an5:110.2.2_0: and a fifth time is comfortable.
an5:111.0.3_0: Someone who was referring to the rafters of the families too deep.
an5:111.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities who visits families is unlikable and unlovable, not respected or admired.
an5:111.1.3_0: They act as though they're close to people they hardly know. They give away things they don’t own. They over-associate with close friends. They whisper in the ear. And they ask for too much.
an5:111.1.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities who visits families is unlikable and unlovable, not respected or admired.
an5:111.2.1_0: A mendicant with five qualities who visits families is dear and beloved, respected and admired.
an5:111.2.3_0: They don’t act as though they're close to people they hardly know. They don’t give away things they don’t own. They don’t over-associate with close friends. They don’t whisper in the ear. And they don’t ask for too much.
an5:111.2.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities who visits families is dear and beloved, respected and admired.”
an5:111.2.5_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:112.0.3_0: From the bank of the river Sappinikā’s attendant.
an5:112.1.1_0: “Mendicants, you shouldn’t take an ascetic with five qualities to follow behind on almsround.
an5:112.1.3_0: They walk too far away or too close behind. They don’t take your bowl when it’s full. They don’t warn you when your speech is bordering on an offense. They keep on interrupting while you’re speaking. And they’re witless, dull, and stupid.
an5:112.1.4_0: You shouldn’t take an ascetic with these five qualities to follow behind on almsround.
an5:112.2.1_0: You should take an ascetic with five qualities to follow behind on almsround.
an5:112.2.3_0: They walk too far away or too close behind. They don’t take your bowl when it’s full. They don’t warn you when your speech is bordering on an offense. They keep on interrupting while you’re speaking. And they’re wise, bright, and clever.
an5:112.2.4_0: You should take an ascetic with these five qualities to follow behind on almsround.”
an5:113.0.3_0: Right immersion should be ruined right immersion.
an5:113.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who has five qualities can’t enter and remain in right immersion.
an5:113.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
an5:113.1.4_0: A mendicant who has these five qualities can’t enter and remain in right immersion.
an5:113.2.1_0: A mendicant who has five qualities can enter and remain in right immersion.
an5:113.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
an5:113.2.4_0: A mendicant who has these five qualities can enter and remain in right immersion.”
an5:114.0.3_0: From the limit of blind ordinary folk.
an5:114.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Andhakavinda.
an5:114.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an5:114.1.2_2: Sitting to one side, the Buddha said to Ānanda:
an5:114.2.1_0: “Ānanda, those mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training should be encouraged, supported, and established in five things.
an5:114.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:114.2.3_0: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in restraint in the monastic code: ‘Reverends, please be ethical. Live restrained in the code of conduct, conducting yourselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’
an5:114.3.1_0: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in restraint in the sense doors: ‘Reverends, please live with kindness. Purecidity, supported by protection, and security.’
an5:114.4.1_0: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in limiting their speech: ‘Reverends, please speak little. Put a limit on your speech.’
an5:114.5.1_0: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in retreat: ‘Reverends, please live in the wilderness. Frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.’
an5:114.6.1_0: They should be encouraged, supported, and established in right perspective: ‘Reverends, please hold right view and have right perspective.’
an5:114.6.2_0: Those mendicants who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training should be encouraged, supported, and established in these five things.”
an5:115.0.3_0: Remember the Both of this fish.
an5:115.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.
an5:115.1.3_0: She is stingy with dwellings, families, material possessions, praise, and the teaching.
an5:115.1.4_0: With these five qualities they’re cast down to hell.
an5:115.2.1_0: A nun ... female who has five qualities is raised up to heaven.
an5:115.2.3_0: She is not stingy with dwellings, families, material possessions, praise, or the teaching.
an5:115.2.4_0: With these five qualities they’re raised up to heaven.”
an5:116.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.
an5:116.1.3_0: Without examining or scrutinizing, they praise those deserving of criticism
an5:116.1.4_0: Without examining or scrutinizing, they criticize those deserving of praise.
an5:116.1.5_0: She arouses faith in things that are dubious,
an5:116.1.6_0: and doesn’t arouse faith in things that are inspiring.
an5:116.1.7_0: And she wastes gifts given in faith.
an5:116.1.8_0: With these five qualities they’re cast down to hell.
an5:116.2.1_0: A nun ... female who has five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5:116.2.6_0: and does arouse faith in things that are inspiring.
an5:116.2.7_0: And she doesn’t waste gifts given in faith.
an5:116.2.8_0: With these five qualities they’re raised up to heaven.”

an5:12.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five powers of a trainee.
an5:12.1.3_0: Faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.
an5:12.1.4_0: These are the five powers of a trainee.
an5:12.1.5_0: Of these five powers of a trainee, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.
an5:12.2.1_0: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
an5:12.2.2_0: In the same way, of these five powers of a trainee, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.
an5:12.3.1_0: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
an5:12.3.2_0: ‘We will have the trainee’s powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.
an5:12.3.2_3: We will have the power of wisdom.’
an5:12.3.3_0: ʻWe will do observance-day ceremonies that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”

an5:121.0.3_0: From the banks of the river Aciravatī
an5:121.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an5:121.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where
an5:121.1.3_0: he saw a certain mendicant who was weak and sick.
an5:121.1.4_0: He sat down on the seat spread out,
an5:121.1.5_0: and told the mendicants what had happened.
an5:121.2.1_0: “Mendicants, if a weak and sick mendicant does not neglect five things, it can be expected that
an5:121.2.2_0: they will soon realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:121.3.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:121.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5:121.3.3_0: If a weak and sick mendicant does not neglect these five things, it can be expected that
an5:121.3.4_0: they will soon realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
an5:121.3.5_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:122.0.3_0: From there he picked upright Hair of mindfulness.
an5:122.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who develops and cultivates five qualities can expect one of two results:
an5:122.1.2_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
an5:122.2.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:122.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has well established mindfulness inside themselves in order to understand the arising and passing away of phenomena, meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observes the impermanence of all conditions.
an5:122.2.3_0: Any monk or nun who develops and cultivates these five qualities can expect one of two results:
an5:122.2.4_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
an5:123.0.3_0: Right here he gathers together as one,
an5:123.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a patient with five qualities is hard to care for.
an5:123.1.3_0: They do what is unsuitable. They don’t know moderation in what is suitable. They don’t take their medicine. Though their carer wants what’s best for them, they don’t accurately report their symptoms by saying when they’re getting worse, getting better, or staying the same. And they cannot endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
an5:123.1.4_0: A patient with these five qualities is hard to care for.
an5:123.2.1_0: A patient with five qualities is easy to care for.
an5:123.2.3_0: They do what is suitable. They know moderation in what is suitable. They take their medicine. Because their carer wants what’s best for them, they accurately report their symptoms by saying when they’re getting worse, getting better, or staying the same. And they can endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
an5:123.2.4_0: A patient with these five qualities is easy to care for.”
an5:124.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a carer with five qualities is not competent to care for a patient.
an5:124.1.4_0: They don’t know what is suitable and unsuitable, so they supply what is unsuitable and remove what is suitable.
an5:124.1.5_0: They care for the sick for the sake of material benefits, not out of love.
an5:124.1.6_0: They’re disgusted to remove feces, urine, vomit, or spit.
an5:124.1.7_0: They’re unable to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the patient with a Dhamma talk from time to time.
an5:124.1.8_0: A carer with these five qualities is not competent to care for a patient.
an5:124.2.1_0: A carer with five qualities is competent to care for a patient.
an5:124.2.4_0: They know what is suitable and unsuitable, so they remove what is unsuitable and supply what is suitable.
an5:124.2.5_0: They care for the sick out of love, not for the sake of material benefits.
an5:124.2.6_0: They’re not disgusted to remove feces, urine, vomit, or spit.
an5:124.2.7_0: They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the patient with a Dhamma talk from time to time.
an5:124.2.8_0: A carer with these five qualities is competent to care for a patient.”
an5:125.0.3_0: Right here he lived for the mung beans:
an5:125.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five things that live without being Form.
an5:125.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:125.1.3_0: Doing what is unsuitable, not knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food unfit for consumption, activity at unsuitable times, and unchastity.
an5:125.1.4_0: These are the five things not transgressed.
an5:125.2.1_0: There are these five things for the life.
an5:125.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:125.2.3_0: Doing what is suitable, knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food fit for consumption, activity at suitable times, and celibacy.
an5:125.2.4_0: These are the five things for long life.”
an5:126.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five things that live without being Form.
an5:126.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:126.1.3_0: Doing what is unsuitable, not knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food unfit for consumption, unethical behavior, and bad friends.
an5:126.1.4_0: These are the five things not transgressed.
an5:126.2.1_0: There are these five things for the life.
an5:126.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:126.2.3_0: Doing what is suitable, knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food fit for consumption, ethical conduct, and good friends.
an5:126.2.4_0: These are the five things for long life.”
an5:127.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is not fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.
an5:127.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is not content with any kind of robe, alms-food, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they have a lot of sensual thoughts.
an5:127.1.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is not fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.
an5:127.2.1_0: A mendicant with five qualities is fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.
an5:127.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, alms-food, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they think a lot about renunciation.
an5:127.2.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.”
an5:128.0.3_0: Just this is the happiness of debate.
an5:128.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of suffering for an ascetic.
an5:128.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is not content with any kind of robe, alms-food, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an5:128.1.4_0: These are five kinds of suffering for an ascetic.
an5:128.2.1_0: There are these five kinds of happiness for an ascetic.
an5:128.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, alms-food, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they lead the spiritual life satisfied.
an5:128.2.4_0: These are five kinds of happiness for an ascetic.”
an5:129.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five fatal wounds lead to a place of loss, to hell.
an5:129.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:129.1.3_0: Murdering your mother or father or a perfected one; maliciously shedding the blood of a Realized One; and causing a schism in the Saṅgha.
an5:129.1.4_0: These five fatal wounds lead to a place of loss, to hell.”

an5:130.1.3_0: loss of relatives, wealth, health, ethics, and view.
an5:130.1.4_0: It is not because of loss of relatives, wealth, or health that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:130.1.5_0: It is because of loss of ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5:130.2.5_0: It is because of endowment with ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5:131.1.1_0: “Mendicants, possessing five factors a wheel-turning monarch wields power only in a principled manner.
an5:131.1.2_0: That wheel cannot be turned back by any human being.
an5:131.2.2_0: A wheel-turning monarch knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.
an5:131.2.3_0: A wheel-turning monarch who possesses these five factors wields power only in a principled manner.
an5:131.2.4_0: That wheel cannot be turned back by any human being.
an5:131.3.1_0: In the same way, possessing five factors a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.
an5:131.3.2_0: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
an5:131.4.2_0: A Realized One knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.
an5:131.4.3_0: Possessing these five factors a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.
an5:131.4.4_0: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
an5:131.4.5_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:132.1.1_0: “Mendicants, possessing five factors a wheel-turning monarch’s eldest son continues to wield the power set in motion by his father only in a principled manner.
an5:132.1.2_0: That wheel cannot be turned back by any human being.
an5:132.2.2_0: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.
an5:132.2.3_0: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son who possesses these five factors continues to wield the power set in motion by his father only in a principled manner.
an5:132.2.4_0: That wheel cannot be turned back by any human being.
an5:132.3.1_0: In the same way, possessing five factors Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.
an5:132.3.2_0: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
an5:132.4.2_0: Sāriputta knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.
an5:132.4.3_0: Possessing these five factors Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.
an5:132.4.4_0: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
an5:133.0.3_0: Peacefulness is the King of Muttā.
an5:133.1.1_0: “Mendicants, even a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, does not wield power without having their own king.”
an5:133.1.2_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
an5:133.1.4_0: “It is principle, monk,” said the Buddha.
an5:133.2.1_0: “Monk, a wheel-turning monarch provides just protection and security for his court, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5:133.3.1_0: He provides just protection and security for his aristocrats, vassals, troops, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
an5:133.3.1_1: When brahmins and householders are handful, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins,
an5:133.3.2_0: When he has done this, he wields power only in a principled manner.
an5:133.3.3_0: That wheel cannot be turned back by any human being.
an5:133.4.1_0: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the monks, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5:133.4.2_0: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated.
an5:133.4.3_0: You should not cultivate such verbal actions.
an5:133.4.4_0: you should not cultivate the kind of mental action that should be cultivated.
an5:133.4.5_0: You should not cultivate that kind of livelihood that should be cultivated.
an5:133.4.6_0: You shouldn’t frequent that kind of village or town.’
an5:133.5.1_0: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the nuns ... laymen ... laywomen, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.
an5:133.5.2_0: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated.
an5:133.5.3_0: You should not cultivate such verbal actions.

an5:133.6.1_0: When a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has provided just protection and security for the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, he rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.
an5:133.6.2_0: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
an5:134.1.1_0: “Mendicants, with five factors an anointed aristocratic king lives in his own realm, no matter what region he lives in.
an5:134.2.2_0: An anointed aristocratic king is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation.
an5:134.2.3_0: He is rich, affluent, and wealthy, with a full treasury and storehouses.
an5:134.2.4_0: He is powerful, having an army of four divisions that is obedient and carries out instructions.
an5:134.2.5_0: He has a counselor who is astute, competent, and intelligent, able to think issues through as they bear upon the past, future, and present.
an5:134.2.6_0: These four things bring his fame to fruition.
an5:134.2.7_0: With these five factors, including fame, an anointed aristocratic king lives in his own realm, no matter what direction he lives in.
an5:134.2.9_0: Because that is how it is for victors.
an5:134.3.10_0: This is like the anointed aristocratic king having a counselor.
an5:134.3.11_0: These four qualities bring their freedom to fruition.
an5:134.3.12_0: With these five qualities, including freedom, they live in their own realm, no matter what region they live in.
an5:134.3.14_0: Because that is how it is for those whose mind is free.”
an5:134.3.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities lives with mind freed, no matter what region they live in.
an5:134.3.3_0: It’s when mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5:134.3.4_0: This is like the anointed aristocratic king’s impeccable lineage.
an5:134.3.5_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:134.3.6_0: This is like the anointed aristocratic king being rich, affluent, and wealthy, with full treasury and storehouses.
an5:134.3.7_0: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5:134.3.8_0: This is like the anointed aristocratic king having power.
an5:134.3.9_0: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an5:139.0.3_0: From the banks of the river Aciravatī
an5:139.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is not worthy of a king, not fit to serve a king, and is not considered a factor of kingship.
an5:139.1.3_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
an5:139.10.1_0: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure sounds?
an5:139.10.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, hearing a sound with their ears, is aroused by a desirable sound, so is not able to still the mind.
an5:139.10.3_0: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure sounds.
an5:139.11.1_0: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure smells?
an5:139.11.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, smelling an odor with their nose, is aroused by a desirable smell, so is not able to still the mind.
an5:139.11.3_0: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure smells.
an5:139.12.1_0: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure tastes?
an5:139.12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, tasting a flavor with their tongue, is aroused by desirable tastes, so is not able to still the mind.
an5:139.12.3_0: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure tastes.
an5:139.13.1_0: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure touches?
an5:139.13.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, feeling a touch with their body, is aroused by a desirable touch, so is not able to still the mind.
an5:139.13.3_0: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure touches.
an5:139.14.1_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is not worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, not worthy of hospitality, not worthy of a religious donation, not worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is not the supreme field of merit for the world.
an5:139.15.1_0: A royal bull elephant with five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5:139.15.3_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
an5:139.16.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure sights?
an5:139.16.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder at the sight of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.
an5:139.16.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure sights.
an5:139.17.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure sounds?
an5:139.17.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant does not falter or founder at the sound of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry, or the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.
an5:139.17.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure sounds.
an5:139.18.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure smells?
an5:139.18.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when it smells the odor of the feces and urine of battle-hardened, pedigree royal bull elephants. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.
an5:139.18.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure smells.
an5:139.19.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure tastes?
an5:139.19.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when it misses a meal of grass and water, or it misses two, three, four, or five meals. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.
an5:139.19.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure tastes.
an5:139.2.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights?
an5:139.2.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders at the sight of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5:139.2.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights.
an5:139.20.1_0: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure touches?
an5:139.20.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when struck by a swift arrow, or by two, three, four, or five swift arrows. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.
an5:139.20.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure touches.
an5:139.21.1_0: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5:139.22.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an5:139.22.3_0: It’s when a mendicant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.

an5:139.23.3_0: That’s how a mendicant can endure sights.

an5:14.1.3_0: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
an5:14.2.1_0: And what is the power of faith?
an5:14.2.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening ...
an5:14.2.3_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
an5:14.2.4_0: This is called the power of faith.
an5:14.3.1_0: And what is the power of energy?
an5:14.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5:14.3.3_0: This is called the power of energy.
an5:14.4.1_0: And what is the power of mindfulness?
an5:14.4.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
an5:14.4.3_0: This is called the power of mindfulness.
an5:14.5.1_0: And what is the power of immersion?
an5:14.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
an5:14.5.3_0: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption ...
an5:14.5.4_0: Through the fading away of joy, they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
an5:14.5.4_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
an5:14.5.5_0: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
an5:14.5.6_0: This is called the power of immersion.
an5:14.6.1_0: And what is the power of wisdom?
an5:14.6.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5:14.6.3_0: This is called the power of wisdom.
an5:140.0.3_0: From the bank of the river Sappinikā’s monastery,
an5:140.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5:140.1.3_0: A royal bull elephant listens, destroys, protects, endures, and goes fast.
an5:140.10.1_0: And how does a mendicant decline?
an5:140.10.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual,
an5:140.10.2_1: They favor malicious oppose malicious intent.
an5:140.10.2_2: or cruel thought that has arisen.
an5:140.10.2_3: They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
an5:140.10.3_0: That’s how a mendicant kills her.
an5:140.11.1_0: And how does a mendicant protect?
an5:140.11.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
an5:140.11.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
an5:140.11.3_2: For the restraint of the eye, he is restraint of the faculty.
an5:140.11.4_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
an5:140.11.5_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
an5:140.11.6_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
an5:140.11.7_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
an5:140.11.8_0: Knowing a thought with his mind, he doesn’t get caught up in the features and details.
an5:140.11.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
an5:140.11.9_1: they protect the faculties of the mind.
an5:140.12.1_0: And how is a mendicant withdrawn?
an5:140.12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism;
an5:140.12.2_1: and one’s displeased by lust; he endures painful physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
an5:140.12.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is patient.
an5:140.13.1_0: And how is a mendicant a secret?
an5:140.13.2_0: It’s when a mendicant swiftly goes in the direction they’ve never gone before in all this long time; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
an5:140.13.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a secret.
an5:140.14.1_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods ...
an5:140.14.1_1: the supreme field of merit for the world.”
an5:140.14.3_0: The fourth sub-chapter on kings is finished.
an5:140.15.4_0: and with the ending of craving.

an5:140.2.4_0: And he pays heed, pays attention, engages wholeheartedly, and lends an ear.
an5:140.2.5_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant becomes a royal bull elephant.
an5:140.3.1_0: And how does a royal bull elephant kill?
an5:140.3.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when it misses a meal of elephants, horses, and chariots, and arches. It stays firm, and plunges into a chariot.
an5:140.3.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant kills.
an5:140.4.1_0: And how does a royal bull elephant protect?
an5:140.4.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle protects its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its fore-feet and hind-feet, and its head, ears, tusks, trunk, tail, and rider.
an5:140.4.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant protects.
an5:140.5.1_0: And how does a royal bull elephant endure?
an5:140.5.2_0: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals.
an5:140.5.3_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant is patient.
an5:140.6.1_0: And how does a royal bull elephant secret?
an5:140.6.2_0: It may be that a royal bull elephant trains, when the elephant trainer says,
an5:140.6.5_0: That’s how a royal bull elephant looks.
an5:140.7.1_0: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5:140.8.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an5:140.8.3_0: A mendicant listens, destroys, protects, endures, and goes fast.
an5:140.9.1_0: And how is a mendicant a scholar?
an5:140.9.2_0: It’s when a mendicant pays heed, pays attention, engages wholeheartedly, and lends an ear when the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One is being taught.
an5:140.9.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a perfected one.
an5:141.0.3_0: Then they took hold of what is meant.
an5:141.1.1_0: “Monks, there are five kinds of people found in the world.
an5:141.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:141.1.3_0: One gives then scorns, one lives together then scorns, one is gullible for gossip, one is impulsive, and one is dull and stupid.
an5:141.2.1_0: And how does a person give then scorn?
an5:141.2.2_0: It’s when a person gives someone robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an5:141.2.6_0: They give to that person, then they scorn them.
an5:141.2.7_0: That’s how a person gives then scorns.
an5:141.3.1_0: And how does a person live together then scorn?
an5:141.3.2_0: It’s when a person lives with someone else for two or three years.
an5:141.3.3_0: They live together with that person, then they scorn them.
an5:141.3.4_0: That’s how a person live together then scorns.
an5:141.4.1_0: And how is a person gullible for gossip?
an5:141.4.2_0: It’s when they’re very quick to believe what a certain person says in praise or criticism of another.
an5:141.4.3_0: That’s how a person is gullible for gossip.
an5:141.5.1_0: And how is a person impulsive?
an5:141.5.2_0: It’s when a certain person is fickle in faith, devotion, fondness, and confidence.
an5:141.5.3_0: That’s how a person is impulsive.
an5:141.6.1_0: And how is a person dull and stupid?
an5:141.6.2_0: It’s when they don’t know the difference between qualities that are skillful and unskillful, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, and those on the side of dark and bright.
an5:141.6.3_0: That’s how a person is dull and stupid.
an5:141.6.4_0: These are the five people found in the world.”
an5:141.6.5_0: First the first part of the body.

an5:142.1.3_0: One person violates and regrets it.

an5:142.5.2_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

an5:142.6.2_0: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
an5:142.6.3_0: You should say this to them:
an5:142.6.4_0: ‘Venerable, the defilements born of violation are found in you, and the defilements born of regret grow. You would do well to give up the defilements born of violation and get rid of the defilements born of regret, and then develop the mind and wisdom.

an5:143.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an5:143.1.2_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
an5:143.1.3_0: Now at that time around five hundred Licchavis were sitting together at the Sārandada shrine, and this discussion came up among them,
an5:143.1.4_0: “The appearance of five treasures is rare in the world.
an5:143.1.6_0: The elephant-treasure, the horse-treasure, the jewel-treasure, the woman-treasure, and the householder-treasure.
an5:143.1.7_0: The appearance of these five treasures is rare in the world.”
an5:143.2.1_0: Then those Licchavis sent a man out on to the road, saying,
an5:143.2.2_0: “Mister, please tell us when you see the Buddha.”
an5:143.2.3_0: That man saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
an5:143.2.4_0: He went to the Licchavis and said,
an5:143.2.5_0: “Sirs, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is coming.
an5:143.3.1_0: And they continued on their way to the Buddha.
an5:143.3.1_1: They approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
an5:143.3.1_2: and told him what had happened, adding:
an5:143.4.1_0: “Please go to the Sārandada shrine, out of compassion.”
an5:143.4.2_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
an5:143.4.3_0: Then the Buddha went up to the Sārandada shrine.
an5:143.4.3_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
an5:143.4.4_0: “Licchavis, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
an5:143.4.5_0: “Well, Master Gotama, this discussion came up among us while we were sitting together:
an5:143.4.6_0: ‘The appearance of five treasures is rare in the world.
an5:143.4.8_0: The elephant-treasure, the horse-treasure, the jewel-treasure, the woman-treasure, and the householder-treasure.
an5:143.4.9_0: The appearance of these five treasures is rare in the world.’”
an5:143.5.1_0: “You Licchavis are so fixated on sensual pleasures, that’s the only discussion that came up!
an5:143.5.2_0: Licchavis, the appearance of five treasures is rare in the world.
an5:143.5.4_0: The appearance of a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
an5:143.5.5_0: A person who explains the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
an5:143.5.6_0: A person who understands the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
an5:143.5.7_0: A person who practices in line with the teaching.
an5:143.5.9_0: The appearance of these five treasures is rare in the world.”
an5:144.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa, in Tikaṇḍakī Wood.
an5:144.2.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant would do well to meditate from time to time perceiving the following: the repulsive in the unrepulsive,
an5:144.2.3_0: the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5:144.2.4_0: the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5:144.2.5_0: A mendicant would do well to meditate from time to time staying equanimous, mindful and aware, rejecting both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5:144.3.1_0: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive?
an5:144.3.2_0: ‘May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed.’
an5:144.3.3_0: For this reason a mendicant should meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive.
an5:144.4.1_0: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive?
an5:144.4.2_0: ‘May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate.’ ...

an5:144.5.2_0: ‘May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed. May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate.’ ...
an5:144.5.3_0: For this reason a mendicant should meditate perceiving the repulsive in both the unrepulsive and the repulsive.
an5:144.6.1_0: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive?
an5:144.6.2_0: ‘May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate. May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed.’ ...
an5:144.6.3_0: For this reason a mendicant should meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5:144.7.1_0: For what reason should a mendicant meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, rejecting both the repulsive and the unrepulsive?
an5:144.7.2_0: ‘May no greed for things that arouse greed, hate for things that provoke hate, or delusion for things that promote delusion arise in me in any way at all.’
an5:144.7.3_0: For this reason a mendicant should meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, rejecting both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.”
an5:145.0.3_0: From the banks of the Sappinī river.
an5:145.1.1_0: “Mendicants, someone with five qualities is cast down to hell.
an5:145.1.3_0: They kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, and use alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
an5:145.1.4_0: Someone with these five qualities is cast down to hell.
an5:145.2.1_0: Someone with five qualities is raised up to heaven
an5:145.2.3_0: She doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or use alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
an5:145.2.4_0: Someone with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”
an5:146.1.1_0: “Mendicants, you shouldn’t associate with a mendicant friend who has five qualities.
an5:146.1.3_0: They start up work projects. They take up disciplinary issues. They conflict with leading mendicants. They like long and aimless wandering. They’re unable to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire you from time to time with a Dhamma talk.
an5:146.1.4_0: Mendicants, you shouldn’t associate with a mendicant friend who has these five qualities.
an5:146.2.1_0: You should associate with a mendicant friend who has five qualities.
an5:146.2.3_0: They don’t start up work projects. They don’t take up disciplinary issues. They don’t conflict with leading mendicants. They don’t like long and aimless wandering. They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire you from time to time with a Dhamma talk.
an5:146.2.4_0: You should associate with a mendicant friend who has these five qualities.”
an5:147.0.3_0: As a consequence they became heir of the bad people.
an5:147.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five gifts of a bad person.
an5:147.1.3_0: They give carelessly. They give thoughtlessly. They don’t give with their own hand. They give the dregs. They give without consideration for consequences.
an5:147.1.4_0: These are the five gifts of a bad person.
an5:147.2.1_0: There are these five gifts of a good person.
an5:147.2.3_0: They give carefully. They give thoughtfully. They give with their own hand. They don’t give the dregs. They give with consideration for consequences.
an5:147.2.4_0: These are the five gifts of a good person.”
an5:148.1.1_0: “There are these five gifts of a good person.
an5:148.1.3_0: Or they give out of faith. They give gift carefully, not with their mind. They don’t need to keep themselves healthy and whole.
an5:148.2.1_0: Having given a gift out of faith, in whatever place the result of that gift manifests they become rich, affluent, and wealthy. And they’re attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.
an5:148.3.1_0: Having given a gift carefully, in whatever place the result of that gift manifests they become rich, affluent, and wealthy.
an5:148.3.2_0: And their children, wives, bondservants, workers, and staff want to listen. They pay attention and try to understand.
an5:148.4.1_0: Having given a gift at the right time, in whatever place the result of that gift manifests they become rich, affluent, and wealthy.
an5:148.4.2_0: And when the time is right, they get all that they need.
an5:148.5.1_0: Having given a gift with no strings attached, in whatever place the result of that gift manifests they become rich, affluent, and wealthy.
an5:148.5.2_0: and the mind inclined to sensual pleasures.
an5:148.6.1_0: Having given a gift without hurting themselves or others, in whatever place the result of that gift manifests they become rich, affluent, and wealthy.
an5:148.6.2_0: And no damage comes to their property from anywhere, whether fire, flood, rulers, bandits, or unloved heirs.
an5:148.6.3_0: These are the five gifts of a good person.”
an5:149.0.3_0: Here the first to be trusted.
an5:149.1.1_0: “These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
an5:149.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:149.1.3_0: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. And they don’t review the extent of their mind’s freedom.
an5:149.1.4_0: These five things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
an5:149.2.1_0: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.
an5:149.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?

an5:149.2.4_0: These five things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

an5:151.1.3_0: They disparage the talk, the speaker, or themselves. They listen with distracted and scattered mind. They attend improperly.
an5:151.1.4_0: Someone with these five qualities is unable to enter the sure path with regards to skillful qualities even when listening to the true teaching.
