an5:156.1.1_0: “These five things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:156.1.3_0: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that they learned incorrectly, with misplaced words and phrases.
an5:156.1.4_0: When the words and phrases are misplaced, the meaning is hard to understand.
an5:156.1.5_0: This is the first thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.10.1_0: Furthermore, the Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.
an5:156.10.2_0: When the Saṅgha is in harmony, they don’t abuse, insult, block, or reject each other.
an5:156.10.3_0: This inspires confidence in those without it,
an5:156.10.4_0: This is the fifth thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:156.10.5_0: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”
an5:156.2.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
an5:156.2.2_0: This is the second thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.3.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—don’t carefully make others recite the discourses.
an5:156.3.2_0: When they pass away, the discourses aren’t cut off at the root, and they have not been plained.
an5:156.3.3_0: This is the third thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.4.1_0: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5:156.4.2_0: those who come after them will follow their example.
an5:156.4.3_0: They too are indulgent and slack ...
an5:156.4.4_0: This is the fourth thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.5.2_0: When the Saṅgha is split, they abuse, insult, block, and reject each other.
an5:156.5.3_0: This doesn’t inspire confidence in those without it, and it causes some with confidence to change their minds.
an5:156.5.4_0: This is the fifth thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.5.5_0: These are five things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an5:156.6.1_0: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:156.6.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:156.6.3_0: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that have been learned correctly, with well placed words and phrases.
an5:156.6.4_0: When the words and phrases are well placed, the meaning is interpreted correctly.
an5:156.6.5_0: This is the first thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:156.7.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants are easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
an5:156.7.2_0: This is the second thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:156.8.1_0: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—carefully make others recite the discourses.
an5:156.8.2_0: When they pass away, the discourses aren’t cut off at the root, and they have someone to preserve them.
an5:156.8.3_0: This is the third thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:156.9.1_0: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
an5:156.9.1_1: rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5:156.9.2_0: those who come after them will follow their example.
an5:156.9.3_0: They too aren’t indulgent or slack ...
an5:156.9.4_0: This is the fourth thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an5:157.0.3_0: It’s inappropriate to speak to someone else.
an5:157.1.1_0: “Mendicants, it is inappropriate to speak to five kinds of person by comparing that person with someone else.
an5:157.1.3_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith.
an5:157.1.4_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics.
an5:157.1.5_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning.
an5:157.1.6_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity.
an5:157.1.7_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom.
an5:157.10.1_0: And why is it appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning?
an5:157.10.2_0: When a learned person is spoken to about learning they don’t lose their temper ...
an5:157.10.4_0: Seeing that learning in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that learning brings.
an5:157.10.5_0: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning.
an5:157.11.1_0: And why is it appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity?
an5:157.11.2_0: When a generous person is spoken to about generosity they don’t lose their temper ...
an5:157.11.4_0: Seeing that generosity in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that generosity brings.
an5:157.11.5_0: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity.
an5:157.12.1_0: And why is it appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom?
an5:157.12.2_0: When a wise person is spoken to about wisdom they don’t lose their temper, they don’t get annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an5:157.12.4_0: Seeing that wisdom in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that wisdom brings.
an5:157.12.5_0: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom.
an5:157.12.6_0: It is appropriate to speak to these five kinds of person by comparing that person with someone else.”
an5:157.2.1_0: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith?
an5:157.2.2_0: When an unfaithful person is spoken to about faith they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an5:157.2.4_0: Not seeing that faith in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that faith brings.
an5:157.2.5_0: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith.
an5:157.3.1_0: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics?
an5:157.3.2_0: When an unethical person is spoken to about ethics they lose their temper ...
an5:157.3.4_0: Not seeing that ethical conduct in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that ethical conduct brings.
an5:157.3.5_0: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics.
an5:157.4.1_0: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning?
an5:157.4.2_0: When an unlearned person is spoken to about learning they lose their temper ...
an5:157.4.4_0: Not seeing that learning in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that learning brings.
an5:157.4.5_0: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning.
an5:157.5.1_0: And why is it inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity?
an5:157.5.2_0: When an stingy person is spoken to about generosity they lose their temper ...
an5:157.5.4_0: Not seeing that generosity in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that generosity brings.
an5:157.5.5_0: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity.
an5:157.6.1_0: And why is it inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom?
an5:157.6.2_0: When a witless person is spoken to about wisdom they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an5:157.6.4_0: Not seeing that wisdom in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that wisdom brings.
an5:157.6.5_0: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom.
an5:157.6.6_0: It is inappropriate to speak to these five kinds of person by comparing that person with someone else.
an5:157.7.1_0: It is appropriate to speak to five kinds of person by comparing that person with someone else.
an5:157.7.3_0: It’s appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith.
an5:157.7.4_0: It’s appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct.
an5:157.7.5_0: It’s appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning.
an5:157.7.6_0: It’s appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity.
an5:157.7.7_0: It’s appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom.
an5:157.8.1_0: And why is it appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith?
an5:157.8.2_0: When a faithful person is spoken to about faith they don’t lose their temper, they don’t get annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
an5:157.8.4_0: Seeing that faith in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that faith brings.
an5:157.8.5_0: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith.
an5:157.9.1_0: And why is it appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct?
an5:157.9.2_0: When an ethical person is spoken to about ethical conduct they don’t lose their temper ...
an5:157.9.4_0: Seeing that ethical conduct in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that ethical conduct brings.
an5:157.9.5_0: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct.
an5:158.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is overcome by timidity.
an5:158.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is faithless, unethical, with little learning, lazy, and witless.
an5:158.1.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is overcome by timidity.
an5:158.2.1_0: A mendicant with five qualities is self-assured.
an5:158.2.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, ethical, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.
an5:158.2.4_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is self-assured.”
an5:159.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
an5:159.1.3_0: Now, at that time Venerable Udāyī was sitting teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.
an5:159.1.6_0: “Sir, Venerable Udāyī is teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.”
an5:159.2.10_0: You should establish these five things in yourself before teaching Dhamma to others.”
an5:159.2.1_0: “Ānanda, it’s not easy to teach Dhamma to others.
an5:159.2.2_0: You should establish five things in yourself before teaching Dhamma to others.
an5:159.2.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:159.2.4_0: You should teach Dhamma to others thinking: ‘I will teach step by step.’ ...
an5:159.2.7_0: ‘I will not teach while secretly hoping to profit.’ ...
an5:159.2.9_0: It’s not easy to teach Dhamma to others.
an5:16.1.3_0: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
an5:16.1.5_0: Of these five powers, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.
an5:16.1.6_0: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
an5:16.1.7_0: In the same way, of these five powers, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.”
an5:160.0.3_0: Peaceful Mind is hard to get rid of thread.
an5:160.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five things are hard to get rid of once they’ve arisen.
an5:160.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:160.1.3_0: Greed, hate, delusion, the feeling of being inspired to speak out, and thoughts of traveling.
an5:160.1.4_0: These five things are hard to get rid of once they’ve arisen.”
an5:160.1.6_0: The first sub-chapter on the true teaching is finished.
an5:160.2.1_0: Three on taking possession of the rightly,
an5:160.2.3_0: It’s inappropriate to talk to a wise person
an5:161.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.10_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.11_0: You should determine a person you resent.
an5:161.1.12_0: ‘This venerable is the owner of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.
an5:161.1.13_0: They shall be the heir of whatever deeds they do, whether good or bad.’
an5:161.1.14_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.15_0: A mendicant should use these five methods to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.”
an5:161.1.16_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:161.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant should use these five methods to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.
an5:161.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:161.1.3_0: You should develop love for a person you resent.
an5:161.1.4_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.5_0: You should develop compassion for a person you resent. ...
an5:161.1.6_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.7_0: You should develop equanimity for a person you resent. ...
an5:161.1.8_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:161.1.9_0: You should disregard a person you resent, paying no attention to them. ...
an5:162.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:162.2.10_0: Such a person should get rid of resentment for another.
an5:162.2.11_0: In the case of a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is pure, and who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time,
an5:162.2.12_0: Such a person should get rid of resentment for another.
an5:162.2.1_0: “Reverends, a mendicant should use these five methods to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.
an5:162.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:162.2.3_0: In the case of a person whose behavior by way of body is impure, but whose behavior by way of speech is pure,
an5:162.2.4_0: Such a person should get rid of resentment for another.
an5:162.2.5_0: In the case of a person whose behavior by way of speech is impure, but whose behavior by way of body is pure, ...
an5:162.2.6_0: Such a person should get rid of resentment for another.
an5:162.2.7_0: In the case of a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, but who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, ...
an5:162.2.8_0: Such a person should get rid of resentment for another.
an5:162.2.9_0: In the case of a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, and who doesn’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, ...
an5:162.3.1_0: How should you get rid of resentment for a person whose behavior by way of body is impure, but whose behavior by way of speech is pure?
an5:162.3.2_0: Suppose a mendicant wearing rag robes sees a rag by the side of the road. They’d hold it down with the left foot, spread it out with the right foot, tear out what was intact, and take it away with them.
an5:162.3.3_0: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that person’s impure behavior by way of body and focus on their pure behavior by way of speech.
an5:162.3.4_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:162.4.1_0: How should you get rid of resentment for a person whose behavior by way of speech is impure, but whose behavior by way of body is pure?
an5:162.4.2_0: Suppose there was a lotus pond covered with moss and aquatic plants.
an5:162.4.3_0: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.
an5:162.4.4_0: They’d plunge into the lotus pond, sweep apart the moss and aquatic plants, drink from their cupped hands, and be on their way.
an5:162.4.5_0: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that person’s impure behavior by way of speech and focus on their pure behavior by way of body.
an5:162.4.6_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:162.5.10_0: on that occasion you should not focus on that impure behavior by way of speech.
an5:162.5.11_0: and focus on the fact that they get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time.
an5:162.5.12_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:162.5.1_0: How should you get rid of resentment for a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, but who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?
an5:162.5.2_0: Suppose there was a little water in a cow’s hoofprint.
an5:162.5.3_0: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.
an5:162.5.5_0: ‘This little bit of water is in a cow’s hoofprint.
an5:162.5.6_0: If I drink it with my cupped hands or a bowl, I’ll stir it and disturb it, making it undrinkable.
an5:162.5.7_0: Why don’t I get down on all fours and drink it up like a cow, then be on my way?’
an5:162.5.9_0: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that person’s impure behavior by way of speech and body,
an5:162.6.10_0: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that person’s impure behavior by way of speech and body, and the fact that they don’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, and think of them with nothing but compassion, kindness, and sympathy:
an5:162.6.11_0: ‘Oh, may this person give up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develop good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:162.6.13_0: So that, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re not reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
an5:162.6.14_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:162.6.1_0: How should you get rid of resentment for a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, and who doesn’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?
an5:162.6.2_0: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and they were sick, suffering, gravely ill.
an5:162.6.3_0: And it was a long way to a village, whether ahead or behind.
an5:162.6.4_0: And they didn’t have any suitable food or medicine, or a competent carer, or someone to bring them to the neighborhood of a village.
an5:162.6.5_0: Then another person traveling along the road sees them,
an5:162.6.6_0: and thinks of them with nothing but compassion, kindness, and sympathy:
an5:162.6.7_0: ‘Oh, may this person get suitable food or medicine, or a competent carer, or someone to bring them to the neighborhood of a village.
an5:162.6.9_0: So that they don’t come to ruin right here.’
an5:162.7.1_0: How should you get rid of resentment for a person whose behavior by way of body and speech is pure, and who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?
an5:162.7.2_0: Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful, and shaded by many trees.
an5:162.7.3_0: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.
an5:162.7.4_0: They’d plunge into the lotus pond to bathe and drink. And after emerging they’d sit or lie down right there in the shade of the trees.
an5:162.8.1_0: In the same way, at that time you should focus on that person’s pure behavior by way of body and speech, and on the fact that they get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time.
an5:162.8.3_0: and focus on the fact that they get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time.
an5:162.8.4_0: In this way you should get rid of resentment.
an5:162.8.5_0: Relying on a person who is impressive all around, the mind becomes confident.
an5:162.9.1_0: A mendicant should use these five methods to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.”
an5:163.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:163.2.1_0: “A mendicant with five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.
an5:163.2.3_0: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in ethics.
an5:163.2.4_0: They’re personally accomplished in immersion, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in immersion.
an5:163.2.5_0: They’re personally accomplished in wisdom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in wisdom.
an5:163.2.6_0: They’re personally accomplished in freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in freedom.
an5:163.2.7_0: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:163.2.8_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.”
an5:164.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:164.0.3_0: As “Intentionality” he lives with his livelihood too early.
an5:164.1.2_0: “A mendicant with five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.
an5:164.1.4_0: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in ethics.
an5:164.1.5_0: They’re personally accomplished in immersion, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in immersion.
an5:164.1.6_0: They’re personally accomplished in wisdom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in wisdom.
an5:164.1.7_0: They’re personally accomplished in freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in freedom.
an5:164.1.8_0: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:164.1.9_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.”
an5:165.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:165.1.1_1: “Whoever asks a question of another, does so for one or other of these five reasons.
an5:165.1.3_0: Someone asks a question of another from stupidity and folly. Or they ask from wicked desires, being naturally full of desires. Or they ask in order to disparage. Or they ask wanting to understand. Or they ask with the thought,
an5:165.1.4_0: ‘If they correctly answer the question I ask it’s good. If not, I’ll correctly answer it for them.’
an5:165.1.5_0: Whoever asks a question of another, does so for one or other of these five reasons.
an5:165.1.6_0: As for myself, I ask with the thought,
an5:165.1.7_0: ‘If they correctly answer the question I ask it’s good. If not, I’ll correctly answer it for them.’”
an5:166.0.2_0: As long as I’ve got rid of resentment.
an5:166.0.3_0: From the Beyond that they know.
an5:166.1.2_0: “Reverend, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5:166.1.4_0: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, then, surpassing the company of gods that consume solid food, they’re reborn in a certain host of mind-made gods. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5:166.10.1_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Udāyī,
an5:166.10.2_0: “But Udāyī, do you believe in a mind-made body?”
an5:166.10.3_0: “For those gods, sir, who are formless, made of perception.”
an5:166.10.4_0: “Udāyī, what has an incompetent fool like you got to say?
an5:166.10.5_0: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!”
an5:166.11.2_0: “Ānanda! There’s a senior mendicant being harassed, and you just watch it happening.
an5:166.11.3_0: Don’t you have any compassion for a senior mendicant who is being harassed?”
an5:166.12.1_0: The Buddha said to the mendicants,
an5:166.12.2_0: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5:166.12.4_0: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, then, surpassing the company of gods that consume solid food, they’re reborn in a certain host of mind-made gods. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5:166.12.6_0: This is what the Buddha said.
an5:166.12.7_0: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
an5:166.13.1_0: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, Venerable Ānanda went to Venerable Upavāṇa
an5:166.13.2_0: “Upavāṇa, take the senior mendicants who harass the senior monks.
an5:166.13.4_0: I wouldn’t be surprised if the Buddha makes a statement about this when he comes out of retreat later this afternoon. He might even call upon Venerable Upavāṇa himself.
an5:166.13.5_0: And right now I feel timid.”
an5:166.13.6_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall.
an5:166.13.6_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
an5:166.14.1_0: “Upavāṇa, how many qualities should a senior mendicant have to be dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired?”
an5:166.14.2_0: “Sir, a senior mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an5:166.14.4_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5:166.14.5_0: He has learned much, and he retained them in good qualities.
an5:166.14.6_0: They’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
an5:166.14.7_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:166.14.8_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life.
an5:166.14.9_0: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”

an5:167.10.1_0: “Even when you speak like this, Sāriputta, there are still some foolish people here who do not respectfully take it up.”
an5:167.11.1_0: “Sir, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued.
an5:167.12.1_0: Sir, there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are dedicated to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise, not stupid. When I speak to them like this, they do respectfully take it up.”
an5:167.13.1_0: “Sāriputta, those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood ... Leave them be.
an5:167.14.1_0: But those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith ... You should speak to them.

an5:181.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of wilderness dwellers.
an5:181.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:181.1.3_0: A person may be wilderness dweller because of stupidity and folly. Or because of wicked desires, being naturally full of desires. Or because of madness and mental disorder. Or because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples. Or for the sake of having few wishes, for the sake of contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and simplicity.
an5:181.1.4_0: These are the five kinds of wilderness dwellers.
an5:181.1.5_0: But the person who dwells in the wilderness for the sake of having few wishes is the foremost, best, chief, highest, and finest of the five.
an5:181.2.1_0: From a cow comes milk, from milk comes curds, from curds come butter, from butter comes ghee, and from ghee comes cream of ghee.
an5:181.2.2_0: In the same way, the person who dwells in the wilderness for the sake of having few wishes is the foremost, best, chief, highest, and finest of the five.”

an5:191.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five traditions of the brahmins are seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:191.1.3_0: In the past brahmins had sex only with brahmin women, not with others.
an5:191.1.4_0: These days brahmins have sex with both brahmin women and others.
an5:191.1.5_0: But these days dogs have sex only with female dogs, not with other species.
an5:191.1.6_0: This is the first tradition of the brahmins seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.2.1_0: In the past brahmins had sex only with brahmin women in the fertile half of the month that starts with menstruation, not at other times.
an5:191.2.2_0: These days brahmins have sex with brahmin women both in the fertile half of the month and at other times.
an5:191.2.3_0: But these days dogs have sex only with female dogs when they are in heat, not at other times.
an5:191.2.4_0: This is the second tradition of the brahmins seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.3.1_0: In the past brahmins neither bought nor sold brahmin women. They lived together because they loved each other and wanted their family line to continue.
an5:191.3.2_0: These days brahmins both buy and sell brahmin women. They live together whether they love each other or not and they want their family line to continue.
an5:191.3.3_0: But these days dogs neither buy nor sell female dogs. They live together because they’re attracted to each other and want their family line to continue.
an5:191.3.4_0: This is the third tradition of the brahmins seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.4.1_0: In the past brahmins did not store up money, grain, silver, or gold.
an5:191.4.2_0: These days brahmins do store up money, grain, silver, and gold.
an5:191.4.3_0: But these days dogs don’t store up money, grain, silver, or gold.
an5:191.4.4_0: This is the fourth tradition of the brahmins seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.5.1_0: In the past brahmins went looking for almsfood for dinner in the evening, and for breakfast in the morning.
an5:191.5.2_0: These days brahmins eat as much as they like until their bellies are full, then take away the leftovers.
an5:191.5.3_0: But these days dogs go looking for dinner in the evening, and for breakfast in the morning.
an5:191.5.4_0: This is the fifth tradition of the brahmins seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.
an5:191.5.5_0: These five traditions of the brahmins are seen these days among dogs, but not among brahmins.”

an5:194.8.1_0: When this was said, the brahmin Kāraṇapālī got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
an5:194.9.1_0: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
an5:195.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an5:195.1.2_0: Now at that time around five hundred Licchavis were visiting the Buddha.
an5:195.1.3_0: Some of the Licchavis were in blue, of blue color, clad in blue, adorned with blue. And some were similarly colored in yellow, red, or white.
an5:195.1.4_0: But the Buddha outshone them all in beauty and glory.
an5:195.2.1_0: Then the brahmin Piṅgīyānī got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
an5:195.2.2_0: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
an5:195.2.3_0: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
an5:195.2.4_0: So the brahmin Piṅgīyānī extolled the Buddha in his presence with a fitting verse.
an5:195.4.1_0: Then those Licchavis clothed Piṅgiyānī with five hundred upper robes.
an5:195.4.2_0: And Piṅgiyānī clothed the Buddha with them.
an5:195.5.1_0: Then the Buddha said to the Licchavis:
an5:195.5.2_0: “Licchavis, the appearance of five treasures is rare in the world.
an5:195.5.4_0: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
an5:195.5.5_0: A person who explains the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
an5:195.5.6_0: A person who understands the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
an5:195.5.7_0: A person who practices in line with the teaching.
an5:195.5.9_0: The appearance of these five treasures is rare in the world.”
an5:196.0.3_0: From the Great Wood, the halls under the peaked roof.
an5:196.1.1_0: “Mendicants, before his awakening five great dreams appeared to the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, when he was still not awake but intent on awakening.
an5:196.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:196.1.3_0: This great earth was his bed. Himalaya, king of mountains, was his pillow. His left hand was laid down in the eastern sea. His right hand was laid down in the western sea. And both his feet were laid down in the southern sea.
an5:196.1.4_0: This is the first great dream that appeared to the Realized One before his awakening.
an5:196.10.1_0: As to when he walked back and forth on top of a huge mountain of filth while remaining unsoiled.
an5:196.10.2_0: This was fulfilled when the Realized One received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And he used them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.
an5:196.10.3_0: This was the fifth great dream that appeared to him while he was still not awakened.
an5:196.11.1_0: Before his awakening these five great dreams appeared to the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, when he was still not awake but intent on awakening.”
an5:196.2.1_0: Next, a kind of grass called ‘the crosser’ grew up from his navel and stood pressing against the cloudy sky.
an5:196.2.2_0: This is the second great dream that appeared to the Realized One before his awakening.
an5:196.3.1_0: Next, white caterpillars with black heads crawled up from his feet and covered his knees.
an5:196.3.2_0: This is the third great dream that appeared to the Realized One before his awakening.
an5:196.4.1_0: Next, four birds of different colors came from the four directions. They fell at his feet, turning pure white.
an5:196.4.2_0: This is the fourth great dream that appeared to the Realized One before his awakening.
an5:196.5.1_0: Next, he walked back and forth on top of a huge mountain of filth while remaining unsoiled.

Himalaya, king of mountains, was his pillow. His left hand was laid down in the eastern sea. His right hand was laid down in the western sea. And both his feet were laid down in the southern sea.
an5:196.6.2_0: This was fulfilled when the Buddha awakened to the perfect awakening.
an5:196.6.3_0: This was the first great dream that appeared to him while he was still not awakened.
an5:196.7.1_0: As to when a kind of grass called ‘the crosser’ grew up from his navel and stood pressing against the cloudy sky.
an5:196.7.2_0: This was fulfilled when, after the Buddha had awakened to the noble eightfold path, it was well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
an5:196.7.3_0: This was the second great dream that appeared to him while he was still not awakened.
an5:196.8.1_0: As to when white caterpillars with black heads crawled up from his feet and covered his knees.
an5:196.8.2_0: This was fulfilled when many white-clothed laypeople went for refuge to him for life.
an5:196.8.3_0: This was the third great dream that appeared to him while he was still not awakened.
an5:196.9.1_0: As to when four birds of different colors came from the four directions. They fell at his feet, turning pure white.
an5:196.9.2_0: This was fulfilled when members of the four castes—aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers—went forth from the lay life to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One and realized supreme freedom.
an5:196.9.3_0: This was the fourth great dream that appeared to him while he was still not awakened.

an5:198.1.1_0: “Mendicants, speech that has five factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
an5:198.1.3_0: It is speech that is timely, true, gentle, beneficial, and loving.
an5:198.1.4_0: Speech with these five factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
an5:199.1.1_0: “When ethical renunciates come to a family, the people make much merit for five reasons.
an5:199.1.3_0: When they see ethical renunciates coming to their family, the people bring up confidence in their hearts. At that time the family is practicing a path leading to heaven.
an5:199.2.1_0: When ethical renunciates come to their family, the people rise from their seats, bow down, and offer them a seat. At that time the family is practicing a path leading to a birth in an eminent family.
an5:199.3.1_0: When ethical renunciates come to their family, the people get rid of the stain of stinginess. At that time the family is practicing a path leading to being illustrious.
an5:199.4.1_0: When ethical renunciates come to their family, the people share what they have as best they can. At that time the family is practicing a path leading to great wealth.
an5:199.5.1_0: When ethical renunciates come to their family, the people ask questions and listen to the teachings. At that time the family is practicing a path leading to great wisdom.
an5:199.5.2_0: When ethical renunciates come to a family, the people make much merit for these five reasons.”

an5:2.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five powers of a trainee.
an5:2.1.3_0: faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.
an5:2.2.1_0: And what is the power of faith?
an5:2.2.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening ...
an5:2.2.3_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
an5:2.2.4_0: This is called the power of faith.
an5:2.3.1_0: And what is the power of conscience?
an5:2.3.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple has a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.
an5:2.3.3_0: This is called the power of conscience.
an5:2.4.1_0: And what is the power of prudence?
an5:2.4.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is prudent. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.
an5:2.4.3_0: This is called the power of prudence.
an5:2.5.1_0: And what is the power of energy?
an5:2.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5:2.5.3_0: This is called the power of energy.
an5:2.6.1_0: And what is the power of wisdom?
an5:2.6.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5:2.6.3_0: This is called the power of wisdom.
an5:2.6.4_0: These are the five powers of a trainee.
an5:2.7.1_0: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
an5:2.7.2_0: ‘We will have the trainee’s powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.
an5:2.7.2_3: We will have the power of wisdom.’
an5:2.7.3_0: That’s how there is should be observance-day ceremonies.”
an5:20.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is practicing for both their own welfare and that of others.
an5:20.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom. And they encourage others in these qualities.
an5:20.1.4_0: They’re personally accomplished in immersion, and encourage others to do the same.
an5:20.1.5_0: They’re personally accomplished in freedom, and encourage others to do the same.
an5:20.1.6_0: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they encourage others to do the same.
an5:20.1.7_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is practicing both for their own welfare and that of others.”

an5:200.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five elements of escape.
an5:200.1.3_0: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on sensual pleasures, but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided about them.
an5:200.1.4_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
an5:200.1.5_0: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from sensual pleasures.
an5:200.1.6_0: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of sensual pleasures, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.
an5:200.1.7_0: This is the escape from sensual pleasures.
an5:200.2.1_0: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on ill will, but their mind isn’t eager ...
an5:200.2.2_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
an5:200.2.3_0: Their mind is in a good state ... well detached from ill will.
an5:200.2.4_0: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of ill will, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.
an5:200.2.5_0: This is the escape from ill will.
an5:200.3.1_0: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on harming, but their mind isn’t eager ...
an5:200.3.2_0: but their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
an5:200.3.3_0: Their mind is in a good state ... well detached from harming.
an5:200.3.4_0: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of harming, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.
an5:200.3.5_0: This is the escape from thoughts.
an5:200.4.1_0: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on form, but their mind isn’t eager ...
an5:200.4.2_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
an5:200.4.3_0: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from form.
an5:200.4.4_0: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of form, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.
an5:200.4.5_0: This is the escape from sights.
an5:200.5.1_0: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on identity, but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided about it.
an5:200.5.2_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
an5:200.5.3_0: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from identity.
an5:200.5.4_0: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of identity, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.
an5:200.5.5_0: This is the escape from identity.
an5:200.6.1_0: Delight in sensual pleasures, ill will, harming, form, and identity don’t linger within them.
an5:200.6.2_0: That’s why they’re called a mendicant who is without underlying tendencies, who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.
an5:200.6.3_0: These are the five elements of escape.”

an5:201.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimibilā in the Bamboo Grove ...
an5:201.1.2_0: Then Venerable Kimbila went up to the Buddha.
an5:201.1.2_2: Then Venerable Kimbila said to the Buddha:
an5:201.1.3_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One?”
an5:201.1.4_0: “Kimbila, it’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen lack respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and each other after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.
an5:201.1.5_0: This is the cause, this is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final extinguishment of the Realized One.”

an5:205.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:205.1.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.
an5:205.1.4_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an5:205.1.5_0: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.
an5:205.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching ...
an5:205.2.4_0: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
an5:205.2.5_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an5:205.2.6_0: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.

an5:206.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five emotional shackles.
an5:206.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:206.1.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
an5:206.1.4_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an5:206.1.5_0: This is the first emotional shackle.
an5:206.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body ...
an5:206.2.2_0: They’re not free of greed for form ...
an5:206.2.3_0: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying, and drowsing ...
an5:206.2.4_0: They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking:
an5:206.2.4_1: ‘By this precept by this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

an5:208.1.1_0: “There are these five disadvantages of not brushing your teeth:
an5:208.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:208.1.3_0: It’s not good for your eyes, you get bad breath, your taste-buds aren’t cleaned, bile and phlegm cover your food, and you lose your appetite.
an5:208.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks of not using chew sticks.
an5:208.2.1_0: There are these five benefits of using chew sticks.
an5:208.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?

an5:208.2.4_0: These are the five benefits of using chew sticks.”

an5:209.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:209.1.3_0: You relish the sound of your own voice. Others relish the sound of your voice. Householders complain:
an5:209.1.4_0: ‘These ascetics, followers of the Sakyan, sing just like us!’ When you’re enjoying the melody, your immersion breaks up. Those who come after follow your example.
an5:209.1.5_0: These are the five drawbacks in reciting with a drawn-out singing sound.”

an5:21.1.3_0: Without fulfilling the practice of a trainee, it’s impossible to fulfill ethics.

an5:210.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:210.1.3_0: you don’t sleep well; you wake up feeling miserable; you have nightmares; the gods don’t guard you; and you emit semen.
an5:210.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks of falling asleep unmindful and unaware.
an5:210.2.1_0: There are these five benefits of falling asleep mindful and aware.
an5:210.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:210.2.3_0: you sleep well; you wake up feeling good; you don’t have nightmares; the gods guard you; and you don’t emit semen.
an5:210.2.4_0: These are the five benefits of falling asleep mindful and aware.”

an5:211.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, can expect these five drawbacks.
an5:211.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:211.1.3_0: They’re expelled, cut off, shut out; or they commit a corrupt offense; or they contract a severe illness. They feel lost when they die. And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:211.1.4_0: A mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, speaking ill of the noble ones, can expect these five drawbacks.”

an5:212.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who starts arguments, quarrels, fights, debates, and disciplinary issues in the Saṅgha can expect five drawbacks.
an5:212.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:212.1.3_0: They don’t achieve the unachieved. What they have achieved falls away. They get a bad reputation. They feel lost when they die. And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:212.1.4_0: A mendicant who starts arguments, quarrels, fights, debates, and disciplinary issues in the Saṅgha can expect these five drawbacks.”
an5:213.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
an5:213.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:213.1.3_0: Firstly, an unethical person loses substantial wealth on account of negligence.
an5:213.10.1_0: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an5:213.10.3_0: These are the five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.”
an5:213.2.1_0: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.
an5:213.3.1_0: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
an5:213.4.1_0: Furthermore, an unethical person feels lost when they die.
an5:213.5.1_0: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:213.5.3_0: These are the five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
an5:213.6.1_0: There are these five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.
an5:213.6.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:213.6.3_0: Firstly, an ethical person gains substantial wealth on account of diligence.
an5:213.7.1_0: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.
an5:213.8.1_0: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
an5:213.9.1_0: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.

an5:214.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for a person who talks a lot.
an5:214.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:214.1.3_0: They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:214.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks for a person who talks a lot.
an5:214.2.1_0: There are these five benefits for a person who talks thoughtfully.
an5:214.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:214.2.3_0: They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an5:214.2.4_0: These are the five benefits for a person who talks thoughtfully.”
an5:215.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of habitually.
an5:215.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:215.1.3_0: Most people find you unlikable and unloveable. You have lots of enmity and many faults. You feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:215.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks of habitually.
an5:215.2.1_0: There are these five benefits of porridge.
an5:215.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:215.2.3_0: Most people find you dear and lovable. You have little enmity and few faults. You don’t feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an5:215.2.4_0: These are the five benefits of porridge.”
an5:216.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of habitually.
an5:216.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:216.1.3_0: Most people find you unlikable and unlovable. You’re cruel and remorseful. You feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an5:216.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks of habitually.
an5:216.2.1_0: There are these five benefits of porridge.
an5:216.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:216.2.3_0: Most people find you likable and lovable. You’re neither cruel nor remorseful. You don’t feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an5:216.2.4_0: These are the five benefits of porridge.”

an5:23.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five corruptions of gold. When gold is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant, but is brittle and not completely ready for working.
an5:23.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:23.1.3_0: Iron, copper, tin, lead, and silver.
an5:23.1.4_0: When gold is corrupted by these five corruptions it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant, but is brittle and not completely ready for working.
an5:23.1.5_0: But when gold has these five corruptions of gold it’s pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is completely ready for working.
an5:23.1.6_0: Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a ring, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.
an5:23.2.1_0: In the same way, there are these five corruptions of the mind. When the mind is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant. It’s brittle, and not completely immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.
an5:23.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:23.2.3_0: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
an5:23.2.4_0: These are the five corruptions of the mind. When the mind is corrupted by these it’s not pliable, workable, or radiant. It’s brittle, and not completely immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.
an5:23.2.5_0: But when the mind is free of these five corruptions it’s pliable, workable, and radiant. It’s not brittle, and is completely immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an5:23.7.1_1: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. an5:232.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an5:232.1.3_0: One who is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. He undertakes and trains in the training rules.
an5:232.1.4_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:232.1.5_0: They’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
an5:232.1.6_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:232.1.7_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:232.1.8_0: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”

an5:249.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks to a charnel ground.
an5:249.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:249.1.3_0: It’s filthy, stinking, frightening, a gathering place for savage monsters, and a weeping place for many people.
an5:249.1.4_0: These are the five drawbacks to a charnel ground.
an5:249.2.1_0: In the same way, there are these five drawbacks of a person like a charnel ground.
an5:249.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:249.2.3_0: To start with, some person has filthy conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:249.2.6_0: This is how they’re filthy, I say.
an5:249.2.7_0: That person is just as filthy as a charnel ground.
an5:249.2.8_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:249.3.1_0: Because of their filthy conduct, they get a bad reputation.
an5:249.3.2_0: This is how they’re stinky, I say.
an5:249.3.3_0: That person is just as stinky as a charnel ground.
an5:249.3.4_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:249.4.1_0: Because of their filthy conduct, good-hearted spiritual companions avoid them from afar.
an5:249.4.2_0: That’s how they’re frightening, I say.
an5:249.4.3_0: That person is just as frightening as a charnel ground.
an5:249.4.4_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:249.5.1_0: Because of their filthy conduct, they live together with people of a similar character.
an5:249.5.2_0: This is how they gather with savage monsters, I say.
an5:249.5.3_0: That person is just as much a gathering place of savage monsters as a charnel ground.
an5:249.5.4_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:249.6.1_0: Because of their filthy conduct, when good-hearted spiritual companions see them they complain:
an5:249.6.2_0: ‘Oh, it’s so painful for us to have to live together with such as these.’
an5:249.6.3_0: This is how there’s weeping, I say.
an5:249.6.4_0: This person is just as much a weeping place for many people as a charnel ground.
an5:249.6.5_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:249.6.6_0: These are the five drawbacks of a person like a charnel ground.”

an5:26.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five opportunities for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at these times, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary.
an5:26.2.2_0: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.
an5:26.2.3_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches it.
an5:26.2.4_0: Not knowing the teaching, joy springs up.
an5:26.2.5_0: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up.
an5:26.2.6_0: the body is full of tranquility.
an5:26.2.7_0: When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.
an5:26.2.8_0: They feel bliss, when they’re happy, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
an5:26.2.9_0: This is the first opportunity for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at this time, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary.
an5:26.3.1_0: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
an5:26.3.2_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they teach it in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
an5:26.3.3_0: Not knowing the teaching, joy springs up.

an5:26.4.2_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they recite it in detail as they learned and memorized it.
an5:26.4.3_0: Not knowing the teaching, joy springs up.

an5:28.14.1_2: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I thus recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.’

an5:28.2.1_0: “And how do you develop noble right immersion with five factors?
an5:28.2.2_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.
an5:28.2.3_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
an5:28.2.3_1: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
an5:28.2.4_0: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water.
an5:28.2.4_1: They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
an5:28.2.5_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
an5:28.2.6_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
an5:28.2.7_0: This is the first way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
an5:28.3.1_0: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption ...
an5:28.3.2_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
an5:28.3.3_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
an5:28.3.4_0: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water.
an5:28.3.4_1: There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time.
an5:28.3.5_0: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake.
an5:28.3.5_1: There’s no part of the lake spread through with cool water.
an5:28.3.6_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
an5:28.3.7_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
an5:28.3.8_0: This is the second way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
an5:28.4.1_0: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

an5:28.4.3_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
an5:28.4.4_0: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater.
an5:28.4.5_0: From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water.
an5:28.4.6_0: There’s no part of them that’s not spread through with cool water.
an5:28.4.7_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture.
an5:28.4.8_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
an5:28.4.9_0: This is the third way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.

an5:28.5.2_0: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind.
an5:28.5.3_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
an5:28.5.4_0: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth.
an5:28.5.5_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with white cloth.

an5:28.5.7_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.

an5:30.1.8_0: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
an5:30.1.9_0: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an5:47.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of wealth.
an5:47.1.3_0: The wealth of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
an5:47.2.1_0: And what is the wealth of faith?
an5:47.2.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening ...
an5:47.2.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
an5:47.2.4_0: This is called the wealth of faith.
an5:47.3.1_0: And what is the wealth of ethics?
an5:47.3.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, or take alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. ...
an5:47.3.2_1: or consume alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
an5:47.3.3_0: This is called the wealth of ethical conduct.
an5:47.4.1_0: And what is the wealth of the wealth?
an5:47.4.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:47.4.3_0: This is called the wealth of ethical conduct.
an5:47.5.1_0: And what is the wealth of generosity?
an5:47.5.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
an5:47.5.3_0: This is called the wealth of generosity.
an5:47.6.1_0: And what is the wealth of wisdom?
an5:47.6.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5:47.6.3_0: This is called the wealth of wisdom.
an5:47.6.4_0: These are the five kinds of wealth.
an5:47.7.1_0: Whoever has faith in the Realized One,
an5:47.8.4_0: his life is not in vain.

an5:50.4.8_2: He went to Nārada, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an5:50.6.5_0: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka the treasurer. He did so, then told the king:
an5:50.7.1_0: Then King Muṇḍa mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp to see Venerable Nārada at the Chicken Monastery.
an5:50.7.2_0: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.
an5:50.7.3_0: Then the king went up to Nārada,
an5:50.8.1_0: “Great king, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
an5:50.8.3_0: That someone liable to old age should not grow old. ...
an5:50.8.4_1: ‘It’s not liable to die, may I not die!’
an5:50.8.4_2: ‘It’s not who is liable to die!’ ...
an5:50.9.1_0: An uneducated ordinary person has someone liable to old age who grows old.
an5:50.9.3_0: ‘It’s not just me who is liable to grow old, as long as they come and go, pass away and are reborn.
an5:50.9.4_0: If I were to purity someone who is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life, their body, speech, and mind would not fall into confusion, because I’d better preemptively pleasures.’
an5:50.9.5_0: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
an5:50.9.7_0: ‘When an uneducated ordinary person enters the street and square torture with poison, he gets down.
an5:51.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an5:51.2.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom.
an5:51.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:51.2.8_0: These are the five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom.
an5:51.3.1_0: Take a mendicant who has feeble and weak wisdom, not having given up these five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom. It’s simply impossible that they would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
an5:51.3.2_0: Suppose there was a mountain river traveling far, flowing fast, carrying all before it.
an5:51.3.3_0: But then a man would open channels on both sides,
an5:51.3.4_0: so the mid-river current would be dispersed, spread out, and separated. The river would no longer flow swiftly, going far, carrying all before it.
an5:51.3.5_0: In the same way, take a mendicant who has feeble and weak wisdom, not having given up these five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom. It’s simply impossible that they would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
an5:51.4.1_0: But take a mendicant who has powerful wisdom, having given up these five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom. It’s quite possible that they would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
an5:51.4.2_0: Suppose there was a mountain river traveling far, flowing fast, carrying all before it.
an5:51.4.3_0: But then a man would close up the channels on both sides,
an5:51.4.4_0: so the mid-river current would not be dispersed, spread out, and separated. The river would keep flowing swiftly for a long way, carrying all before it.
an5:51.4.5_0: In the same way, take a mendicant who has powerful wisdom, having given up these five obstacles and hindrances, parasites of the mind that weaken wisdom. It’s quite possible that they would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.”
an5:51.4.6_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:52.1.1_0: “Mendicants, rightly speaking, you’d call the five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.
an5:52.1.2_0: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.
an5:52.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:52.1.4_0: the hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
an5:52.1.5_0: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.
an5:52.1.6_0: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.”
an5:53.1.10_0: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an5:53.1.11_0: These are the five factors that support meditation.”
an5:53.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five factors that support meditation.
an5:53.1.3_0: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
an5:53.1.4_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
an5:53.1.5_0: They are rarely ill or unwell.
an5:53.1.6_0: Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.
an5:53.1.8_0: They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.
an5:53.1.9_0: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an5:54.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five times that are not good for meditation.
an5:54.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:54.1.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant is old, overcome with old age.
an5:54.1.4_0: This is the first time that’s not good for meditation.
an5:54.10.1_0: Furthermore, the Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.
an5:54.10.2_0: When the Saṅgha is in harmony, they don’t abuse, insult, block, or reject each other.
an5:54.10.3_0: This inspires confidence in those without it,
an5:54.10.4_0: This is the fifth time that’s good for meditation.
an5:54.10.5_0: These are the five times that are good for meditation.”
an5:54.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is sick, overcome by sickness.
an5:54.2.2_0: This is the second time that’s not good for meditation.
an5:54.3.1_0: Furthermore, there’s a famine, a bad harvest, so it’s hard to get alms-food, and not easy to keep going by collecting alms.
an5:54.3.2_0: This is the third time that’s not good for meditation.
an5:54.4.1_0: Furthermore, there’s peril from wild savages, and the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
an5:54.4.2_0: This is the fourth time that’s not good for meditation.
an5:54.5.2_0: When the Saṅgha is split, they abuse, insult, block, and reject each other.
an5:54.5.3_0: This doesn’t inspire confidence in those without it, and it causes some with confidence to change their minds.
an5:54.5.4_0: This is the fifth time that’s not good for meditation.
an5:54.5.5_0: These are the five times that are not good for meditation.
an5:54.6.1_0: There are five times that are good for meditation.
an5:54.6.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:54.6.3_0: Firstly, a mendicant is a youth, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
an5:54.6.4_0: This is the first time that’s good for meditation.
an5:54.7.1_0: Furthermore, they are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

an5:54.8.2_0: This is the third time that’s good for meditation.
an5:54.9.1_0: Furthermore, people live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
an5:54.9.2_0: This is the fourth time that’s good for meditation.
an5:55.1.10_0: With their minds swamped by lust, without resigning the training and declaring their inability to continue, they had sex.
an5:55.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an5:55.1.2_0: Now, at that time a mother and son had both entered the rainy season residence at Sāvatthī,
an5:55.1.3_0: as a monk and a nun.
an5:55.1.4_0: They wanted to see each other often.
an5:55.1.5_0: The mother wanted to see her son often,
an5:55.1.7_0: Seeing each other often, they became close.
an5:55.1.8_0: Being so close, they became intimate.
an5:55.1.9_0: And being intimate, lust overcame them.
an5:55.10.1_0: But those who completely understand sensual pleasures,
an5:55.10.2_0: live fearing nothing from any quarter.
an5:55.10.3_0: They are those in the world who’ve crossed over,
an5:55.10.4_0: Those who have ended the defilements.
an5:55.2.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha.
an5:55.2.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
an5:55.2.2_0: And they told him what had happened.
an5:55.2.3_0: The monks and nuns wanted to see each other as their mother.
an5:55.2.4_0: Seeing each other often, they became close. Being afraid of wrongdoing, they had sexual intercourse with their mind. They had sexual intercourse when they’re weaked. And when they were weakened, they had sexual intercourse with their minds.”
an5:55.3.1_0: “Mendicants, how could that silly man imagine that
an5:55.3.2_0: a mother cannot lust for her son, or that a son cannot lust for his mother?
an5:55.3.3_0: Compared to the sight of a woman, I do not see a single sight that is so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, captivating, and infatuating, and such an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary.
an5:55.3.4_0: Sentient beings are lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, and attached to the sight of a woman.
an5:55.3.5_0: They sorrow for a long time under the sway of a woman’s sight.
