an5:56.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to his own mentor,
an5:56.1.1_1: Then the preceptor went up to his own mentor, and said,
an5:56.1.2_0: “Now, sir, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”
an5:56.2.1_0: The monk took the student and went to the Buddha.
an5:56.2.3_0: ‘Now, sir, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.’”
an5:56.3.1_0: “That’s how it is, mendicant, when your sense doors are unguarded, you eat too much, you’re not dedicated to wakefulness, you’re unable to discern skillful qualities, and you don’t pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn. Your body feels like it’s drugged. You’re disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill your mind. You lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.
an5:56.3.2_0: So you should train like this:
an5:56.3.3_0: ‘I will guard my sense doors, eat in moderation, be dedicated to wakefulness, discern skillful qualities, and pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn.’
an5:56.4.1_0: When he had been given this advice by the Buddha, that monk got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
an5:56.4.2_0: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
an5:56.4.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
an5:56.4.4_0: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.
an5:56.5.1_0: When that monk had attained perfection, he went to his own mentor,
an5:56.5.1_1: Then the preceptor went up to his own mentor, and said,
an5:56.5.2_0: “Now, sir, my body doesn’t feel like it’s drugged. I’m not disorientated, the teachings spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness don’t fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life satisfied, and have no doubts about the teachings.”
an5:56.5.3_0: The monk took the student and went to the Buddha.
an5:56.5.5_0: ‘Now, sir, my body doesn’t feel like it’s drugged. I’m not disorientated, the teachings spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness don’t fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life satisfied, and have no doubts about the teachings.’”
an5:56.6.1_0: “That’s how it is, mendicant, when your sense doors are guarded, you’re moderate in eating, you’re dedicated to wakefulness, you’re able to discern skillful qualities, and you pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn. Your body doesn’t feel like it’s drugged. You’re not disorientated, the teachings spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness don’t fill your mind. You lead the spiritual life satisfied, and have no doubts about the teachings.
an5:56.6.2_0: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
an5:56.6.3_0: ‘We will guard our sense doors, eat in moderation, be dedicated to wakefulness, discern skillful qualities, and pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn.’
an5:56.6.4_0: ʻWe will do observance-day ceremonies that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”
an5:57.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate should often review these five subjects.
an5:57.1.3_0: ‘I am liable to grow old, I am not exempt from old age.’ A woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate should often review this.
an5:57.1.4_0: ‘I am liable to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness.’ ...
an5:57.1.5_0: ‘I am liable to die, I am not exempt from death.’ ...
an5:57.1.6_0: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’ ...
an5:57.1.7_0: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.
an5:57.1.8_0: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’
an5:57.1.9_0: A woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate should often review this.
an5:57.10.1_0: ‘It’s not just me who must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved. For all sentient beings must be parted and separated from all they hold dear and beloved, as long as they come and go, pass away and are reborn.’
an5:57.10.2_0: Reviewing this subject often, they perceive the path for the next life.
an5:57.10.4_0: By doing so, they give up the fetters and eliminate the underlying tendencies.

an5:57.11.3_0: Reviewing this subject often, they perceive the path for the next life.

an5:57.2.1_0: What is the advantage for a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to grow old, I am not exempt from old age’?
an5:57.2.2_0: There are sentient beings who, intoxicated with the vanity of youth, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:57.2.3_0: Reviewing this subject often, they entirely give up the vanity of youth, or at least reduce it.
an5:57.2.4_0: This is the advantage for a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to grow old, I am not exempt from old age’.
an5:57.3.1_0: What is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness’?
an5:57.3.2_0: There are sentient beings who, drunk on the vanity of health, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:57.3.3_0: Reviewing this subject often, they entirely give up the vanity of health, or at least reduce it.
an5:57.3.4_0: This is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to get sick, I am not exempt from sickness’.
an5:57.4.1_0: What is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to die, I am not exempt from death’?
an5:57.4.2_0: There are sentient beings who, drunk on the vanity of life, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:57.4.3_0: Reviewing this subject often, they entirely give up the vanity of life, or at least reduce it.
an5:57.4.4_0: This is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I am liable to die, I am not exempt from death’.
an5:57.5.1_0: What is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved’?
an5:57.5.2_0: There are sentient beings who, aroused by desire and lust for their dear and beloved, do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an5:57.5.3_0: Reviewing this subject often, they entirely give up desire and lust for their dear and beloved, or at least reduce it.
an5:57.5.4_0: This is the advantage of often reviewing this: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved’.

an5:58.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an5:58.1.2_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
an5:58.1.3_0: Then after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he plunged deep into the Great Wood and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
an5:58.10.1_0: Furthermore, a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth to honor, respect, esteem, and venerate those who work the neighboring fields, and those he does business with.
an5:58.10.2_0: Honored in this way, ascetics and brahmins love him with a good heart, wishing:
an5:58.10.3_0: ‘For a long time now, Dīgha Tapassī!’
an5:58.10.4_0: When a gentleman is loved by ascetics and brahmins, you can expect only growth, not decline.
an5:58.11.1_0: You can expect only growth, not decline, when you find these five qualities in any gentleman—
an5:58.11.2_0: whether he’s an anointed aristocratic king, an appointed or hereditary official, an army general, a village chief, a guild chief, or a ruler of his own clan.
an5:58.12.1_0: He’s always dutiful to his mother and father,
an5:58.12.2_0: and for the good of his wives and children.
an5:58.12.3_0: He looks after those in his household,
an5:58.12.4_0: and those dependent for their livelihood:
an5:58.13.2_0: looks after the welfare of relatives—
an5:58.13.3_0: both those who have passed away,
an5:58.14.1_0: While living at home, an astute person
an5:58.14.2_0: uses legitimate means to give rise to joy
an5:58.15.4_0: and he departs to rejoice in heaven.”
an5:58.2.1_0: Now at that time several Licchavi youths took strung bows and, escorted by a pack of hounds, were going for a walk in the Great Wood when they saw the Buddha seated at the root of a tree.
an5:58.2.2_0: When they saw him, they put down their strung bows, tied their hounds up to one side, and went up to him.
an5:58.2.2_1: They went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
an5:58.3.1_0: Now at that time Mahānāma the Licchavi was going for a walk in the Great Wood when he saw those Licchavi youths silently paying homage to the Buddha with joined palms.
an5:58.3.2_0: Seeing this, he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
an5:58.3.4_0: “They will make it as Vajjis! They will make it as Vajjis!”
an5:58.4.1_0: “But Mahānāma, why do you say that they will make it as Vajjis?”
an5:58.4.2_0: ‘They will make it as Vajjis! They will make it as Vajjis!’”
an5:58.4.3_0: “Sir, these Licchavi youths are violent, harsh, and brash.
an5:58.4.4_0: They’re given up the families, tied to the roots, mung beans, lentils, chickpeas, or jump back, wrap gather them with a stick or a stone.
an5:58.4.5_0: And they hit women and girls of good families on their backs.
an5:58.4.6_0: But now they’re silently paying homage to the Buddha with joined palms.”
an5:58.5.1_0: “Mahānāma, a gentleman can expect five qualities
an5:58.5.2_0: “Mahānāma, you can expect only growth, not decline, when you find five qualities in any gentleman—whether he’s an anointed aristocratic king, an appointed or hereditary official, an army general, a village chief, a guild chief, or a ruler of his own clan.
an5:58.6.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:58.6.2_0: Firstly, a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth—earned by his efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow—to honor, respect, esteem, and venerate his mother and father.
an5:58.6.3_0: Honored in this way, his mother and father love him with a good heart, wishing:
an5:58.6.4_0: ‘For a long time now, Dīgha Tapassī!’
an5:58.6.5_0: When a gentleman is loved by his mother and father, you can expect only growth, not decline.
an5:58.7.1_0: Furthermore, a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth to honor, respect, esteem, and venerate his wives and children, bondservants, workers, and staff.
an5:58.7.2_0: Honored in this way, his wives and children, bondservants, workers, and staff love him with a good heart, wishing:
an5:58.7.3_0: ‘For a long time now, Dīgha Tapassī!’
an5:58.7.4_0: When a gentleman is loved by his wives and children, bondservants, workers, and staff, you can expect only growth, not decline.
an5:58.8.1_0: Furthermore, a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth to honor, respect, esteem, and venerate those who work the neighboring fields, and those he does business with.
an5:58.8.2_0: Honored in this way, those who work the neighboring fields, and those he does business with love him with a good heart, wishing:
an5:58.8.3_0: ‘For a long time now, Dīgha Tapassī!’
an5:58.8.4_0: When a gentleman is loved by those who work the neighboring fields, and those he does business with, you can expect only growth, not decline.
an5:58.9.1_0: Furthermore, a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth to honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the deities who receive spirit-offerings.
an5:58.9.2_0: Honored in this way, the deities who receive spirit-offerings love him with a good heart, wishing:
an5:58.9.3_0: ‘For a long time now, Dīgha Tapassī!’
an5:58.9.4_0: When a gentleman is loved by the deities, you can expect only growth, not decline.
an5:59.1.1_0: “Mendicants, it’s hard to find someone gone forth when old who has five qualities.
an5:59.1.3_0: It’s hard to find someone gone forth when old who is sophisticated, well-presented, and learned, who can teach Dhamma, and has memorized the texts on monastic training.
an5:59.1.4_0: It’s hard to find someone gone forth when old who has these five qualities.”

an5:60.1.1_0: “Mendicants, it’s hard to find someone gone forth when old who has five qualities.

an5:61.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:61.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless.
an5:61.1.3_0: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, dissatisfaction with the whole world, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.
an5:61.1.4_0: These five perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless.”
an5:61.1.5_0: First the first part of the body.
an5:62.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:62.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless.
an5:62.1.3_0: The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.
an5:62.1.4_0: These five perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless.”
an5:63.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:63.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a male noble disciple who grows in five ways grows nobly, taking on what is essential and excellent in this life.
an5:63.1.3_0: He grows in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
an5:63.1.4_0: A male noble disciple who grows in these five ways grows nobly, taking on what is essential and excellent in this life.
an5:63.2.1_0: He who grows in faith and ethics,
an5:63.2.4_0: takes on what is essential for herself in this life.”
an5:64.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:64.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a female noble disciple who grows in five ways grows nobly, taking on what is essential and excellent in this life.
an5:64.1.3_0: He grows in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
an5:64.1.4_0: A female noble disciple who grows in these five ways grows nobly, taking on what is essential and excellent in this life.
an5:64.2.1_0: She who grows in faith and ethics,
an5:64.2.3_0: She is virtuous, ethical, and virtuous,
an5:64.2.4_0: takes on what is essential for herself in this life.”
an5:65.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:65.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.
an5:65.1.3_0: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in ethics.
an5:65.1.4_0: They’re personally accomplished in immersion, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in immersion.
an5:65.1.5_0: They’re personally accomplished in wisdom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in wisdom.
an5:65.1.6_0: They’re personally accomplished in freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in freedom.
an5:65.1.7_0: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:65.1.8_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.”
an5:66.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:66.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.
an5:66.1.3_0: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions posed when discussing accomplishment in ethics.
an5:66.1.4_0: They’re personally accomplished in immersion, and they answer questions posed when discussing accomplishment in immersion.
an5:66.1.5_0: They’re personally accomplished in wisdom, and they answer questions posed when discussing accomplishment in wisdom.
an5:66.1.6_0: They’re personally accomplished in freedom, and they answer questions posed when discussing accomplishment in freedom.
an5:66.1.7_0: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions posed when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an5:66.1.8_0: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.”
an5:67.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:67.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who develops and cultivates five qualities can expect one of two results:
an5:67.1.2_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
an5:67.2.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:67.2.2_0: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort ...
an5:67.2.3_0: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort ...
an5:67.2.4_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort ...
an5:67.2.5_0: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.
an5:67.2.6_0: And the fifth is sheer vigor.
an5:67.2.7_0: Any monk or nun who develops and cultivates these five qualities can expect one of two results:
an5:67.2.8_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
an5:68.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:68.1.1_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still not awake but intent on awakening—I developed and cultivated five things.
an5:68.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:68.1.3_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.
an5:68.1.4_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort ...
an5:68.1.5_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort ...
an5:68.1.6_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.
an5:68.1.7_0: And the fifth is sheer vigor.
an5:68.1.8_0: When I had developed and cultivated these five things, with vigor as fifth,
an5:68.1.9_0: I was capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an5:68.2.1_1: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power’ ...
an5:68.2.2_0: I was capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
an5:68.3.1_1: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
an5:68.3.2_0: I was capable of realizing it, in each and every case.”
an5:69.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:69.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
an5:69.2.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:69.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5:69.2.3_0: These five things, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”
an5:7.0.2_0: This is the power of trainees.
an5:7.1.11_0: I admit she’d know, ‘This will distress the child,
an5:7.1.13_0: But it’s because we want to do what’s best for you, out of kindness and compassion.
an5:7.1.14_0: But when that boy is elderly, overcome by wisdom, a person thinks:
an5:7.1.15_0: ‘The boy can look after himself. He won’t be negligent.’
an5:7.1.1_0: “Mendicants, sentient beings are mostly charmed by sensual pleasures.
an5:7.1.2_0: When a gentleman has abandoned the scythe and flail and gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a faithful renunciate from a good family’.
an5:7.1.4_0: Because a youth can get sensual pleasures of this kind or that.
an5:7.1.5_0: Now, all sensual pleasures are just reckoned as ‘sensual pleasures’, regardless of whether they’re inferior, average, or superior.
an5:7.1.6_0: Suppose there was a little baby boy who, because of his nurse’s negligence, puts a stick or stone in his mouth.
an5:7.1.7_0: The nurse would very quickly notice
an5:7.1.8_0: and try to take it out.
an5:7.1.9_0: If that didn’t work, she’d cradle his head with her left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of her right hand, even if it drew blood.
an5:7.2.1_0: In the same way, I still need to look after a mendicant who hasn’t finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities.
an5:7.2.2_0: But when a mendicant has finished developing faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities, I need not be concerned, thinking:
an5:7.2.3_0: ‘They can look after themselves. They won’t be negligent.’”
an5:70.0.2_0: Perceptions in line with the teaching.
an5:70.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, lead to the ending of defilements.
an5:70.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:70.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5:70.1.4_0: These five things, when developed and cultivated, lead to the ending of defilements.”

an5:71.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when these five things are developed and cultivated they realize the fruit and benefit of freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.
an5:71.2.1_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:71.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5:71.2.3_0: When these five things are developed and cultivated they realize the fruit and benefit of freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.
an5:71.2.4_0: When a mendicant has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom,
an5:71.2.5_0: they’re called a mendicant who has lifted up the cross-bar, filled in the trench, and pulled up the pillar; they’re unbarred, a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.
an5:71.3.1_0: And how has a mendicant ejected that’s how
an5:71.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5:71.3.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has been ejected.
an5:71.4.1_0: And how has a mendicant filled in the trench?
an5:71.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up transmigrating through births in future lives, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5:71.4.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has filled in the trench.
an5:71.5.1_0: And how is a mendicant who has less than four years of seniority?
an5:71.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5:71.5.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has less than four years of seniority.
an5:71.6.1_0: And how is a mendicant withdrawn?
an5:71.6.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.
an5:71.6.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is hill.
an5:71.7.1_0: And how is a mendicant a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached?
an5:71.7.2_0: It’s when they’ve given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5:71.7.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.”

an5:73.0.3_0: He lives in the first absorption
an5:73.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
an5:73.1.2_0: “Sir, they speak of one who lives in line with the teaching.
an5:73.1.3_0: How is a mendicant who lives in this teaching?”
an5:73.2.1_0: “Mendicant, take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an5:73.2.2_0: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications.
an5:73.2.3_0: They spend their days studying that teaching. But they neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.
an5:73.2.4_0: they’re called a mendicant who has mastered the teaching, not against the teaching.
an5:73.3.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
an5:73.3.2_0: They spend their days advocating that teaching. But they neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.
an5:73.3.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who is learned, not remembering the teachings.
an5:73.4.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant recites the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it.
an5:73.4.2_0: They spend their days reciting that teaching. But they neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.
an5:73.4.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who is full of joy, not in the teaching.
an5:73.5.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
an5:73.5.2_0: They spend their days thinking about that teaching. But they neglect retreat, and are not committed to internal serenity of heart.
an5:73.5.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who is full of thought, but not a lot of thoughts.
an5:73.6.1_0: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an5:73.6.2_0: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications.
an5:73.6.3_0: They don’t spend their days studying that teaching. They don’t neglect retreat, and they’re committed to internal serenity of heart.
an5:73.6.4_0: That’s how a mendicant lives in the teaching.
an5:73.7.1_0: So, mendicant, I’ve taught and pointed out what is taught and pointed out by many thoughts. That’s how much of the teaching and training taught.
an5:73.7.2_0: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
an5:73.7.3_0: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
an5:73.7.3_1: Practice absorption, mendicant! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
an5:73.7.3_2: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
an5:74.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,

an5:74.6.3_0: And they do understand the higher meaning.
an5:74.6.4_0: That’s how a mendicant lives in the teaching.
an5:74.7.1_0: So, mendicant, I’ve taught and pointed out what is taught and pointed out by many thoughts. That’s how much of the teaching and training taught.
an5:74.7.2_0: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
an5:74.7.3_0: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.

an5:74.7.3_2: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
an5:75.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five kinds of warriors in the world.
an5:75.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:75.1.3_0: Firstly, one warrior falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5:75.1.4_0: And a warrior is a warrior.
an5:75.1.5_0: This is the first warrior found in the world.
an5:75.10.1_0: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5:75.10.2_0: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5:75.10.3_0: Declaring his inability to continue training, he rejects it and returns to a lesser life.
an5:75.10.5_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, when a female comes up to him. She smiles, chats, laughs, and teases him.
an5:75.10.6_0: He falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5:75.10.7_0: Declaring his inability to continue training, he rejects it and returns to a lesser life.
an5:75.11.1_0: I say that this person is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5:75.11.2_0: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil.
an5:75.11.3_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:75.11.4_0: In this way he’s a person.
an5:75.11.5_0: This is the third person found among the mendicants.
an5:75.12.1_0: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,
an5:75.12.2_0: but their frets are struck by arrow.
an5:75.12.4_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and lie down.
an5:75.12.5_0: Without resigning the training and declaring his inability to continue, he has sex.
an5:75.13.1_0: I say that this person is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, but is killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5:75.13.2_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:75.13.3_0: In this way he’s a person.
an5:75.13.4_0: This is the fourth person found among the mendicants.
an5:75.14.1_0: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5:75.14.3_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and lie down.
an5:75.14.4_0: Without resigning the training and returning to a female.
an5:75.14.5_0: And they frequent a secluded lodging.
an5:75.15.1_0: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down cross-legged, with his body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there.
an5:75.15.2_0: Giving up desire for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
an5:75.15.3_0: Giving up ill will and malevolence, he meditates with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
an5:75.15.4_0: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
an5:75.15.5_0: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
an5:75.15.6_0: Giving up doubt, they meditate without getting rid of doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
an5:75.15.7_0: I gave up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
an5:75.15.8_0: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption ...
an5:75.15.9_0: enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
an5:75.16.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
an5:75.16.2_0: He truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
an5:75.16.3_0: He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
an5:75.16.4_0: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an5:75.16.5_0: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
an5:75.16.6_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
an5:75.17.1_0: I say that this person is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5:75.17.2_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
an5:75.17.3_0: In this way he’s a person.
an5:75.17.4_0: This is the fifth person found among the mendicants.
an5:75.17.5_0: These five people similar to warriors are found among the mendicants.”

an5:75.2.3_0: And a warrior is a warrior.
an5:75.2.4_0: This is the second warrior found in the world.

an5:76.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five kinds of warriors in the world.
an5:76.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:76.1.3_0: Firstly, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.
an5:76.1.4_0: He is able to make an effort to battle.
an5:76.1.5_0: but his foes kill him and finish him off.
an5:76.1.6_0: And a warrior is a warrior.
an5:76.1.7_0: This is the first warrior found in the world.

an5:76.10.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives supported by a town or village.
an5:76.10.2_0: He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters a village or town, guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
an5:76.10.3_0: There they see a female scantily clad, with revealing clothes.
an5:76.10.5_0: With a mind plagued by desire, they burn with the body.

an5:76.10.8_0: I’m overcome with sensual desire, and I don’t fail to keep up the spiritual life.
an5:76.10.9_0: We’ll resign the training and return to a lesser life.’

an5:76.12.4_0: Declaring his inability to continue training, he rejects it and returns to a lesser life.

an5:77.0.3_0: From the banks of the Sappinī river.
an5:77.1.1_0: “Mendicants, seeing these five future perils is quite enough for a wilderness mendicant to meditate diligently, keenly, and resolutely for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5:77.2.3_0: ‘Currently I’m staying alone in the wilderness.
an5:77.2.5_0: I might get bitten by a snake, a scorpion, or a centipede.
an5:77.2.6_0: which would be an obstacle to me.
an5:77.2.7_0: I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
an5:77.2.8_0: This is the first future peril ...
an5:77.3.2_0: ‘Currently I’m staying alone in the wilderness.
an5:77.3.4_0: I might stumble and fall, or get food poisoning, or my bile or phlegm or stabbing wind might get upset.
an5:77.3.5_0: which would be an obstacle to me.
an5:77.3.6_0: I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
an5:77.3.7_0: This is the second future peril ...
an5:77.4.2_0: ‘Currently I’m staying alone in the wilderness.
an5:77.4.4_0: I might encounter wild beasts—a lion, a tiger, a leopard, a bear, or a hyena—which might take my life.
an5:77.4.5_0: which would be an obstacle to me.
an5:77.4.6_0: I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
an5:77.4.7_0: This is the third future peril ...
an5:77.5.2_0: ‘Currently I’m staying alone in the wilderness.
an5:77.5.4_0: I might encounter youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, and they might take my life.
an5:77.5.5_0: which would be an obstacle to me.
an5:77.5.6_0: I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
an5:77.5.7_0: This is the fourth future peril ...
an5:77.6.2_0: ‘Currently I’m staying alone in the wilderness.
an5:77.6.3_0: But in a wilderness there are savage monsters who might take my life.
an5:77.6.4_0: which would be an obstacle to me.
an5:77.6.5_0: I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
an5:77.6.6_0: This is the fifth future peril ...
an5:77.7.1_0: These are the five future perils, seeing which is quite enough for a wilderness mendicant to meditate diligently, keenly, and resolutely for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.”
an5:78.1.1_0: “Mendicants, seeing these five future perils is quite enough for a mendicant to meditate diligently, keenly, and resolutely for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an5:78.1.4_0: ‘Currently I’m a youth, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
an5:78.1.5_0: But there will come a time when this body is struck with old age.
an5:78.1.6_0: When you’re old, overcome by old age, it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas, and it’s not easy to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an5:78.1.7_0: When I’ve seen the truth, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable,
an5:78.1.8_0: I’d better preempt it by rousing up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. That way, when it happens, I’ll live comfortably even though I’m old.’
an5:78.1.9_0: This is the first future peril ...
an5:78.2.2_0: ‘Currently, I’m rarely ill or unwell. My stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.
an5:78.2.3_0: But there will come a time when this body is struck with sickness.
an5:78.2.4_0: When you’re sick, overcome by sickness, it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas, and it’s not easy to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an5:78.2.5_0: When I’ve seen the truth, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable,
an5:78.2.6_0: I’d better preempt it by rousing up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. That way, when it happens, I’ll live comfortably even though I’m sick.’
an5:78.2.7_0: This is the second future peril ...
an5:78.3.2_0: ‘Currently, there’s plenty of food, a good harvest, so it’s easy to get alms-food, and easy to keep going by collecting alms.
an5:78.3.3_0: But there will come a time of famine, a bad harvest, when it’s hard to get alms-food, and not easy to keep going by collecting alms.
an5:78.3.4_0: In a time of famine, people move to where there’s plenty of food,
an5:78.3.5_0: They live diligently in their own dwelling.
an5:78.3.6_0: When it’s secluded, it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas, and it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas.
an5:78.3.7_0: When I’ve seen the truth, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable,
an5:78.3.8_0: I’d better preempt it by rousing up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. That way, when it happens, I’ll live comfortably even though there’s a famine.’
an5:78.3.9_0: This is the third future peril ...
an5:78.4.2_0: ‘Currently, people live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
an5:78.4.3_0: But there will come a time of peril from wild savages, when the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
an5:78.4.4_0: In a time of peril, people move to where there’s sanctuary,
an5:78.4.5_0: They live diligently in their own dwelling.
an5:78.4.6_0: When it’s secluded, it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas, and it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas.
an5:78.4.7_0: When I’ve seen the truth, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable,
an5:78.4.8_0: I’d better preempt it by rousing up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. That way, when it happens, I’ll live comfortably even in a time of peril.’
an5:78.4.9_0: This is the fourth future peril ...
an5:78.5.2_0: ‘Currently, the Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.
an5:78.5.3_0: But there will come a time of schism in the Saṅgha.
an5:78.5.4_0: When there is schism in the Saṅgha, it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas, and it’s not easy to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
an5:78.5.5_0: When I’ve seen the truth, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable,
an5:78.5.6_0: I’d better preempt it by rousing up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized. That way, when it happens, I’ll live comfortably even though there’s schism in the Saṅgha.’

an5:87.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a senior mendicant with five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an5:87.1.3_0: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places.
an5:87.1.3_1: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5:87.1.4_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:87.1.5_0: They’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
an5:87.1.6_0: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5:87.1.7_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:87.1.8_0: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is dear and beloved to their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”
an5:88.0.2_0: The senior monk should take her away.

an5:93.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five ways of declaring enlightenment.
an5:93.1.3_0: One declares enlightenment out of stupidity and folly.
an5:93.1.4_0: Or because of wicked desires, being naturally full of desires.
an5:93.1.5_0: Or because of madness and mental disorder.
an5:93.1.8_0: These are the five ways of declaring enlightenment.”
an5:94.1.1_0: “There are these five kinds of comfort.
an5:94.1.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
an5:94.1.3_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
an5:94.1.4_3: enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
an5:94.1.5_0: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
an5:95.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.
an5:95.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant has attained the textual analysis of meaning, text, terminology, and eloquence, and they review the extent of their mind’s freedom.
an5:95.1.4_0: A mendicant who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”
an5:96.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant cultivating mindfulness of breathing who has five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.
an5:96.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant is easy to admonish, having few wishes, and responsibility.
an5:96.1.6_0: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an5:96.1.8_0: A mendicant cultivating mindfulness of breathing who has these five things will soon penetrate the unshakable.”

an5:99.1.1_0: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den,
an5:99.1.3_0: looks all around the four directions,
an5:99.1.4_0: and roars his lion’s roar three times.
an5:99.1.5_0: and roars his lion’s roar three times.
an5:99.1.6_0: If he strikes an elephant, he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5:99.1.8_0: If he strikes an elephant, he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5:99.2.1_0: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an5:99.2.3_0: When the Realized One teaches the monks ...
an5:99.2.5_0: When the Realized One teaches the Dhamma ...
an5:99.2.7_0: or ordinary people—even food-carriers and hunters—he teaches them carefully, not carelessly.
an5:99.2.9_0: Because the Realized One has respect and reverence for the teaching.”
